B0007Y4TVU|3.0|System of a Down broke into the  music industry with a bang with both their release of their self-titled debut and a headlining place on the Ozzfest tour. Singles such as Sugar and Spiders enjoyed some air space, but the band remained on the fringes of rock even at a time when music was getting heavier (about the same time as Korn and Limp Bizkit's popularity). With their second release, Toxicity, the band delivered some major hits including Chop Suey, Toxicity, and Aerials. Their bland of playful, aggressive, and quasi-political funk metal became so popular that they were able to recycle songs from B-sides and their pre-label days with Steal this Album. Then the band took a little break and began to fade from the airwaves. They finally came to release a new CD, which is of course Mezmerize.  <br /> <br />This CD marks the most drastic change System of a Down has made to their music since they began. Unfortunantly, most of the changes are for the worse. The most noticable change is in the tone of the guitar. In previous albums, the guitar had a distinctive hard edged sound. Now, for some reason, the guitars sound like 80s heavy metal (not neccessarily a bad thing, but different). We also now get to hear A LOT more singing from the guitarist rather than the lead singer (once again not a bad thing, but different). Lastly, the songs seem more drawn out...more tedious. This is because while in earlier albums SOD had no problem cutting their songs to a minute and a half or two minutes they now feel compelled to make the songs 3, 4, and even 5 minutes long. By doing this, SOD loses some of the short and sweet songs that dominated other CDs and seem to be trying to make every track into a single. In general, the CD does not feel like SOD. With all that said, taken independently of other efforts this is not a bad CD. It has variety, an interesting pace and feel, and the CD will eventually grow on you. I would recommend purchase, but I would caution hardcore fans that this is something different. <br /> <br />The first track is a light intro. Immediately, we then jump into BYOB, the band's first single from the album. If you like this song, great. I hate it. But even if you don't like it, don't be concerned it is one of the weakest songs on the CD. <br /> <br />Revenga is the closest thing we get to classic SOD. However, the guitar just sounds bizarre and a throw back to the 80s. We also get a lot of singing from the guitarist here, which I think added a lot to the song. <br /> <br />Cigaro at first comes off as really stupid. It begins \\"My c*ck is much bigger than yours,\\" and it gets even more immature. It's not exactly clear if they're trying to be sarcastic, but even if they are it's a cheap trick. Cigaro also has a very annoying bridge between the chorus and bridge where the guitar plays some odd backwards scale with high pitched vocals. Yet, this song may eventually grow on you. <br /> <br />Radio/Video sounds like it was meant to be single (which is why I ask why did they make BYOB a single?) Yet, the song suffers from more lame lyrics and some odd musical interludes. I really like what they did with the Beatles-esque harmonies midway through the song (we'll hear more of this on Lost in Hollywood). The buildup to the end is also very interesting. In all a very bizarre track that'll eventually grow on you. It really is completely unlike anything SOD has done before. <br /> <br />The Cocaine... once again has a guitar sound completely foreign to SOD. It actually sounds like one of those poppy hard rock groups like Godsmack. The song is a bit repetitive and doesn't really go anywhere. <br /> <br />Violent Pornography is a decent song. It was one of my favorites when I first heard the CD, but on repeated listenings it's not that interesting.  <br /> <br />Question reminds me of a bad version of Toxicity. The singing is kind of grating and purposely off key and tempo. Honestly, this song kind of makes me disoriented. <br /> <br />Thebeginning of Sad Statue sounds like something out of Slayer (once again, not a problem, just different). But after the intro the song wonders a bit, but does have a strong sing-a-long chorus and some good interludes. This is one of my favorite songs on the album. But that isn't saying much...only an above average track. <br /> <br />Old School Hollywood. I don't know what they were thinking with this one. It certainly is bizarre. I can't say it's a bad song, but I think they can do better. If the CD was an hour long I could see including this, but why would you have it on a CD less than 40 minutes long. <br /> <br />Lastly we get Lost in Hollywood whose problems symbolize all of my criticisms towards this band. First let me say, musically it is a superb song full of Beatles-esque harmonies and great singing from the guitarist. With that out of the way, let me assault SOD, the supposed next Rage Against the Machine, for not making a political album. With this song, with its beautiful melodies and deep sound, which makes it perfect for radioplay, SOD should have tried to SAY SOMETHING. In the middle of such politically important events dominating our lives, couldn't have SOD have done something useful. At first, when I heard 'faggots' (for the amazon guy, faggots refers to ciggarrettes) I thought they're going to say something about gay marriage or something. Nope. As far as I can tell they only used it to rhyme with maggots. That's plain stupid. First of all, assuming they were being playful in choosing that word, they should have known that the word would now be played all over the airwaves. If they just used to fill the song, it was a mistake, because it's a very distracting term. With this song, SOD really blew a chance to say something. This is all part of a wider complaint with this band. Rather than do something constructive, they just pretend to be political. Instead of maybe talking about Nagorno-Karabagh...perhaps pushing for some kind of reconciliation withAzurris (I should add that this band is VERY well known in the Armenian community), all they talk about is Turkish recognition of genocide. It's an important subject, but they could be doing more to affect the lives of people today. Instead of singing a song about how empty Los Angeles is (like that's an original theme, pfft) perhaps they could have said something about Iraq or the Middle East in general and how Americans perceive what's going on there. All we get is this stupid song about something everybody already knows is stupid. It's like singing a song making fun of rapists. Say something interesting. <br /> <br />My rant aside, this CD signals a bizarre departure by SOD from the distinctive sound. The songs aren't bad, they just are odd. With enough listens you'll probably begin to enjoy it, but the CD still does not have the consistency or punch of their other records.

6300182193|4.0|I saw this film when it first came out and I never wanted to see another Dracula again. The reason -- Frank Langella as the Prince of Darkness! The 1979 version of the film was translated from Broadway but was first done on the London stage back in the 20s with guess who playing the title role. Langella reprises the role for Broadway with brilliant and Gothic inspired sets by Edward Gory and the Tony awards flew at the production. <br /> <br />Most appealing and still the highlight of the film version is the seduction of Lucy (Kate Nelligan) and the visceral presentation of vampire lust in the not so Victorian sense. Langella nibbles ear lobes instead of chomping necks and his style is hotter than hot with Lucy, a dinner guest who chooses to stay rather than protect her maidenly virtue of the era. <br /> <br />Director John Badham shot on location in Cornwall near Penzance and the moody appearance of the English countryside is transferred to the film. The wonderful actors Sir Lawrence Olivier as Abraham Van Helsing and Donald Pleasence as the always hungry asylum doctor are scene stealers. Both the gruesome and grotesque is never shielded on screen as Mina turns from sickly to ghoulish with Dracula's help. Interior settings are technically right, the elements of the period setting perfect for the ensemble cast. <br /> <br />However, it is Langella's Dracula that changed the perception of the vile seducer of young women with his performance. Unlike the Lugosi and Christopher Lee performances, Langella's vampire is a lover, he waltzes to the \\"Blue Danube,\\" and women will want to parade in a nightgown forever with him as did stunning Nelligan's Lucy, whose duo coffin snuggle is both erotic and protective of her \\"man.\\" <br /> <br />Subtle costume touches include small bat-like winged caplets and dresses for Lucy, and dashing opera capes and cravats for Langella. If there is one element not sufficiently examined in Badham's film, it is the sense of impending doom that Dracula brings from his home via the coffins of earth from Transylvania to English soil, a xenophobia which Bram Stoker underscored in his novel. However, it is a minor point overlooked in a film which stands head and fangs above so many mediocre interpretations available today. It is simply THE bodice heaver adaptation from the late 70s.

B000001ESP|5.0|\\"Moving Pictures\\" finds the band firing on all cylinders, delivering track after track of perfectly crafted and performed prog-rock goodness.  \\"Tom Sawyer\\" and \\"Limelight,\\" (one of the few near-perfect rock songs, in my opinion), deserve their status as classics, as does the frenetic instrumental \\"YYZ\\" which gives each member a chance to showcase their abundant chops.  The lesser-known but atmospheric \\"Witch Hunt\\" and the Police-inspired \\"Vital Signs\\" give the album different musical dimensions, but the high-point is the sprawling \\"Camera Eye,\\" Rush's last long prog epic. <br /> <br />The entire album is brilliantly conceived, musically and lyrically.  There are no slow spots and no filler; the whole album flows perfectly from start to finish, a main reason why it gets 5 stars (I usually don't give perfect reviews).  Alex, Geddy and Neil found their first true taste of mainstream success with this one, offering the perfect blend of challenging, yet accessible and radio-friendly music.  This is not to the album's detriment, however, as Rush always makes their music their way, the listening tastes of the public be damned; the two just happened to coincide in 1981.  Five stars all the way.  If you're curious to get into Rush, start here (I sure did!)  If you're a Rush fan, you already have this one.  Peace.
B00005JOGU|5.0|The most striking thing about this movie is Philip Seymour Hoffman's performance as Truman Capote.  For everyone out there who remembers how Capote acted, this performance is spot-on. 0449002632|5.0|London: The Novel takes us through twenty centuries of the history of the second millennium's greatest city. Rutherfurd uses the format he employed in Sarum, Russka and later in The Forest, and Princes of Ireland, wherein he follows the same families through centuries. These dozen or so chapters in London's history move us forward from Julius Caesar's invasion thru the coming of Christianity, the Saxon times and the Norman Conquest, the construction of the Tower of London, the reign of Henry II, the building of London Bridge, the Black Death, Henry VIII, the Reformation, the Elizabethan Age, the Civil War and Commonwealth, the eighteenth-century, the nineteenth, the rise of the Victorians, the world wars, and the arrival at this present time we can momentarily call the modern age. Rutherfurd's intricately-woven stories are excellent, and in many instances are told with a bawdiness left out in his other novels. Sometimes his plots are a bit like Chaucer's in their good natured perversity. But this is only true in a few places, mostly this is strong, serious storytelling that pilots a reader thru history and gives a good idea of how London came to be what it is today. Another nice feature of this book is that Rutherfurd imports characters from Sarum, so that we meet old friends again and discover branches of families from Wiltshire whose business and migrations have taken them to the capital. Later in the work I was impressed with the detail given to the trials and tribulations Londoners endured during the Blitz, when Nazi Germany did everything in its power to burn their home town to its foundations. I truly enjoyed reading London and found it  a lot of fun. Fans of Rutherfurd's past novels, those who enjoy history, or simply who appreciate a masterfully-crafted series of stories should like it, too.

0440180295|3.0|Kurt Vonnegut is the novel's author and one of the main characters in the novel. In the first and last chapters, Vonnegut speaks about himself, the story he is writing, and what led him to write it.  <br /> <br />     The novel is a very satirical story about the bombing of Dresden by the British. It is clear that many of the war occurrences of Billy Pilgrim, the main character, are autobiographical in life. His appearance in the book complicates the plot and the point of view. Vonnegut himself was a prisoner of war during the firebombing of Dresden, and he occasionally inserts himself in the narrative. Kurt Vonnegut executes an odd, but creative way of authorial existence that reappears throughout the novel. Such examples of when Vonnegut appears and exists are when the novel mentions him or his idea particularly in the refrain \\"So it goes\\" that follows each reference of death. Vonnegut's commentary as a character and an author allows a more factual understanding of a story that seems supernaturally imaginary and adds structure to the idea that such fictional elements may be the reality of a disturbed mind.  <br /> <br />     Another large area of this book is based on the satire on society. One account of satire is how the Tralfamadorians, made up aliens in the mind of Billy Pilgrim, control how he thinks of death. Since the Tralfamadorians think of death as just a \\"state of being\\", Billy consists of that idea, too. It is almost as if death is made as a joke.  <br /> <br />     My overall opinion of this book is fair. This book can be very confusing to read. It jumps from subject to subject. Although the novel may seem out of order, it is very creative in showing the satirical realties in society. I suggest this book for readers interested in satirical novels who can be accepting to displaced ideas, yet creative thoughts social order.
B00012FXB8|4.0|There is an understandable tendency to view this as the least successful of the Alien series.  I think this is more due to its curious handling of the entire alien plotline which cheerfully combines the usual, 'alien chases humans who then chase it,' fare with a startling mystical vision.  There is a great deal of symbol dropping, but the references to biblical myth never quite gel.  Director David Finchley never quite overcomes the hurdles that this aspect of the film presents, but he actually does quite well with everything else, so the film really deserves a second chance.<br /><br />Stanza three of this tale finds us momentarily aboard Ripley's escape vessel, just long enough to become aware that there is an alien with them and to see the ship crash on yet another grim, unpleasant planet.  Ripley is the only survivor and finds that here rescuers are the remnants of a prison colony.  When this colony of double y chromosome criminals was closed several years before, a small group that had found some comfort chose to remain along with a two warders and the prison doctor.  A rescue ship is due for her 'sometime' but the prison's unrelieved post-modern gothic setting is poor comfort to Ripley in the meanwhile.<br /><br />This film makes no effort to hide the awful truth.  Even as Ripley cremates her fellow escapees, we get to watch the birth of yet another of mankind's nemeses in the endless bowels of the prison.  Once again, a hungry alien starts treating humans as snacks.  Ripley attempts to alert the wardens but all is useless.  Her only friends are Clemens (Charles Dance), the prison medic, and Dillon (Charles S. Dutton), the prisoner who doubles as one of the strangest religious leaders in interstellar space.  It isn't until it is clear that something awful is stalking the inmates that the cast settles down to fighting, running, and being munched.<br /><br />The story has quite a few twists as Ripley gradually realizes that the Alien is hardly the worst of her problems.  There are many opportunities for strong character acting and the cast makes the most of almost all of them.  Even the alien has it's moments.  With countless tunnels and dark corners the film has all the room it needs for plenty of action and the bloodthirsty won't feel the least bit disappointed.<br /><br />As I've already said Finchley has cast our hungry xenomorph as the Beast of the Apocalypse.  I can't say as how I blame him (the aliens do represent the end of life as humans think of it), but the imagery is so overstated that many viewers will be put off.  For one, I liked both the filmic and musical moments that were so redolent of monastic appearances.  But, while they added atmospheric depth, they never really advanced the plot, which focused more on the countless acts of heroism that made up the prisoner's defensive efforts.  For being society's dregs, they will quickly win your sympathy.opportunities for strong character acting and the cast makes the most of almost all of them.  Even the alien has it's moments. It isn't until the battle that some of us can pick up that she doesn't want to live anymore and that's when she's hurt badly. Again the movie asks for your full atention and that's something for the masses that can be hard to give. <br /> <br />Other than what's stated above, that the movie was really everything that I wanted in \\"Serenity\\". It's just a good movie. It's not the best ever, but it's the best out this year. It's a credit to the Science Fiction community, however lukewarm they may be to us. <br /> <br />Thank you for your time.

B00006AW2G|5.0|I am not a Rolling Stones fanatic.  In fact, this is the only album of theirs I own, and often when I hear some of their other songs on the radio I change the station.<br /><br />But \\"Let it Bleed\\" is a great album.  The friend who introduced it to me was convinced it was actually a greatest hits collection, and it often feels like it.  Every song is good, great even, although not every song is \\"Written by Mick Jagger & Keith Richards\\" as the liner notes claim: everyone knows \\"Love in Vain\\" is a Robert Johnson tune, though the Rolling Stones do cover it well here.  Some of the songs have a blues feel, others feel like a country bar, and others are nothing but rock and roll anthems, and good ones.  Instrumentation includes harp, piano, mandolin, slide guitar, fiddle, horns, and a boys choir, and the sound is always fluid and bold and energetic.<br /><br />The songs include the frantic, lightning-filled \\"Gimme Shelter,\\" the friendly \\"Let it Bleed,\\" and the sad yet hopeful \\"You Can't Always Get What You Want.\\"<br /><br />This is the Rolling Stones for people who don't neccesarily even like the Rolling Stones.  This is classic rock for people who might even hate that term.  This is just good music, and it's well deserving of its reputation, and well worth buying.<br /><br />Buy it used, though--these guys have enough money, and they take just a little too much pleasure in sueing anyone that samples even a single note of their music.
0671027387|5.0|Deception Point contains all the characteristics of an amazing thriller novel.  Dan Brown continues his amazing writing style that captured audiences all around the world with Angels and Demons and The DaVinci Code.  Deception Point can be an extremely enjoyable manuscript.  If a person likes to read mystery semi-nonfiction thriller books then the person must read it.  The author did a marvelous job in combining characters and a story line that contains the immaculate power to lure readers in, just like his other texts.  Readers will be sure to enjoy every second of this book along with its roller coaster twists and turns.  Dan Brown always knows just how to please audiences and this work has the same effect.  His plots and reader knowledge completely capture all audiences.  The text has been a continuous read without many breaks in between.  If a reader ever feels like reading a nonstop thriller then Deception Point will be that transcript.<br /><br />Deception Point starts off in the remote areas of the arctic where a murder has just been committed.  Just like Dan Brown's other copies he doesn't stay with one topic for long.  So after the murder prologue he jumps to Washington D.C. during a presidential campaign.  This area of the novel shows all the main characters.  Rachel Sexton, the main character of the story, happens to stumble head first into one of the greatest fictional cover-ups ever written.  Rachel and the other characters have to find out about mysterious fossils, their origin, and just how they all came to be in the arctic.  The book, just like its predecessors, sure has many twists and turns that will keep the reader glued to it the whole time.
B000A3DFZE|4.0|One of the great things about Clapton has always been his willingness to share his personal life with his fans through his music.  When he was battling a heroine addiction, he recorded 461 Ocean Boulevard that included `Mainline Florida.'  When his son was tragically killed, he shared `Tears in Heaven' on the soundtrack to the movie Rush and `The Circus Left Town' on Pilgrim.  Clapton's tune may have changed on Back Home, but his proclivity to offer a perspective into his own world has not.<br /><br />In the liner notes, Clapton includes in his dedication, \\"Most of all, I want to thank my wife and children for providing for me, with love and care, the home I have always yearned for, and will always hurry back to.\\"  So, if there had been any doubt, Back Home is the next chapter in Clapton's musical autobiography.  In this installment, Clapton finds the love and family that he believes has eluded him until now, and, the listener need look no further than the first cut, `So Tired' for confirmation.  Not only does Clapton croon lines like, \\"The baby's already feeding, the other one is teething\\" and \\"I just can't wait until the sun's gone down, and all the kids have gone to bed,\\" but he also includes \\"baby sounds,\\" laughing, gurgling, and so forth on the track.  In `Run Home To Me' Clapton laments the good times are good but far too infrequent:<br /><br />I walked down to the water with my love and my baby.<br /><br />Watched the waves breaking in and enjoying the view.<br /><br />And I heard myself saying, \\"We should do this more often.\\"<br /><br />Watch the little ones playing on that bright stony shore,<br /><br />And I wish deep down in my heart we could stay here forever.<br /><br />And, these sweet simple moments never come back no more.<br /><br />Clapton penned six of the 12 songs on Back Home, and other songwriters like Stevie Wonder, George Harrison, Doyle Bramlett II, and Vince Gill also contributed and provided some variety to the CD.  Still, many of Clapton's songs have familiar chords and at least parts of some melodies.  There are a number of examples of some musical recycling.  `Say What You Will' and `Revolution' are written the Reggae rhythm reminiscent of `I Shot The Sheriff.'  Parts of the melody for `Run Home To Me' are similar to `You Were There' from Pilgrim.  Other aspects of that familiar musical style, however, like the Hammond organ and the guitar solo on `One Day' remind the listener that Clapton is still Clapton.<br /><br />In spite of what can be considered mostly unremarkable, adult contemporary songs, it is evident that Clapton is very comfortable in his own musician's skin.  He does not push to make a song something that it's not.  Although vocally Clapton has a warm, comfortable style, he is limited in his range and he realizes that fact.  His guitar virtuosity is not overdone; rather it nicely complements the other musicians, who are as usual, exceptional.  Recognizable names like bassist Nathan East, who has recorded with E.C. for about 20 years beginning with the LP August, Grammy winner Billy Preston, Doyle Bramlett II, Andy Fairweather Low, and percussionist Steve Gadd complete the foundation of Clapton's band.  Other contributors include Chris Stainton, Steve Winwood, Stephen Marley, Vince Gill, and The Kick Horns.<br /><br />While Clapton did not really break any new musical ground with Back Home, it is certainly better than 99.9% of the music (if it can be called that) being produced today.  After all, it IS Clapton.  There are not any hits, but there really does not need to be.  This chapter of Clapton's life in music is well produced and enjoyable for any Clapton aficionado or anyone who wants to hear a living musical treasure.  And, the listener and Clapton fan will ask the same question as Clapton himself asks on the title cut, \\"What next?\\"<br /><br />It will be interesting to find out.ar chords and at least parts of some melodies.  There are a number of examples of some musical recycling.  `Say What You Will' and `Revolution' are written the Reggae rhythm reminiscent of `I Shot The Sheriff.'  Parts of the melody for `Run Home To Me' are similar to `You Were There' from Pilgrim. 0515125024|5.0|Jack Reacher is a huge, well muscled construction of anomalies. He is, certainly, a highly skilled ex-Military Policeman. He lacks the wisecracks of Paul Brenner, DeMille's ex-military cop (The General's Daughter; Up Country), for which this reviewer is grateful. He travels alone, supplementing his discharge settlement from the Army with a number of odd jobs, doorman, pool digger, body guard.<br /><br />Here he is walking on the Chicago streets when he sees Holly Johnsen, on crutches, struggling with her dry cleaning. Of course, it probably helps that despite the crutches, Holly is a drop dead fox.<br /><br />As he goes to assist the damsel in distress, she is grabbed by thugs and in what can only be termed only as an error of judgment of monumental proportions on their part, so is he. Not surprisingly, all hell breaks loose. Retribution may not be swift but you can count on Mr. Child. It is brutal.<br /><br />Lee Child does a great job with the 'man with no name' analogy, and the stories have developed their own cult following. There is a repetitive criticism that Reacher gets involved with these crimes by \\"coincidence.\\" Seeing a damsel in distress. Protecting an aging blues singer on the comeback trail. Seeing a restaurant owner shaken down by Eastern European hoods. Being picked up while hitchiking by a woman with no where to go. Rubbish.<br /><br />One of the greatest directors ever, Hitchcock, loved the \\"coincidental\\" irony in his protagonists getting caught up with life and death situations. See L.B. Jefferies, photographer, in \\"Rear Window.\\" Then see Roger O. Thornhill, advertising agent in \\"North By Northwest.\\" What a great way to start a story.<br /><br />Keep up the great work Mr. Child. 5 stars. Larry Scantlebury

B00000IFP6|5.0|I was curious to listen to David Zinman and the Zurich Orchestra after all I had read in  the CD guide books and magazines. This is my sixth full cycle (Karajan 1963 and 1977, Klemperer,Bernstein/VPO and Toscanini) and these days is definetely my favourite. Zinman brings new life to the symphonies- period. The Barenreiter edition may play a role in the freshness of the music but the passion of maestro and orchestra makes you feel as if you are present in the music hall, being a spectator of a live performance.<br />The first symphonies were the greatest surprise for me, and I can now see the maturation of Beethoven, where as the older approaches interepreted these pieces as small \\"Eroicas\\". There is no doubt there are better interepretations of individual symphonies out there - ex. Carlos Kleiber on the 5th, Klemperer on the \\"Eroica\\"-old style or Furtwangler on the 1952 recording of the \\"Choral\\" - but this fact can not overshadow what I find as an excellent set at a great price.

B000002WPI|5.0|along with Dr. Dre's The Chronic, the Wu-Tang Clan's debut, Enter the Wu-Tang (36 Chambers), was one of the most influential rap albums of the '90s. its spare yet atmospheric production -- courtesy of RZA -- mapped out the sonic blueprint that countless other hardcore rappers would follow for years to come. it laid the groundwork for the rebirth of New York hip-hop in the hardcore age, paving the way for everybody from Biggie and Jay-Z to Nas and Mobb Deep. moreover, it introduced a colorful cast of hugely talented MCs, some of whom ranked among the best and most unique individual rappers of the decade. some were outsized, theatrical personalities, others were cerebral storytellers and lyrical technicians, but each had his own distinctive style, which made for an album of tremendous variety and consistency. every track on Enter the Wu-Tang is packed with fresh, inventive rhymes, which are filled with martial arts metaphors, pop culture references (everything from Voltron to Lucky Charms cereal commercials to Barbra Streisand's \\"The Way We Were\\"), bizarre threats of violence, and a truly twisted sense of humor. their off-kilter menace is really brought to life, however, by the eerie, lo-fi production, which helped bring the raw sound of the underground into mainstream hip-hop. starting with a foundation of hard, gritty beats and dialogue samples from kung fu movies, RZA kept things minimalistic, but added just enough minor-key piano, strings, or muted horns to create a background ambience that works like the soundtrack to a surreal nightmare. there was nothing like it in the hip-hop world at the time, and even after years of imitation, Enter the Wu-Tang still sounds fresh and original. subsequent group and solo projects would refine and deepen this template, but collectively, the Wu have never been quite this tight again.
B000B2YQX4|2.0|TRATARE DE SER LO MAS BREVE POSIBLE: HAY QUE ACEPTAR COMO BUEN FAN DE DEPECHE MODE QUE LA BANDA DEJO DE SER HACE YA TIEMPO LO QUE FUE EN LOS 80'S Y PRINCIPIOS DE LOS 90'S. <br />PLAYING THE ANGEL ME VUELVE A DEJAR INCOMPLETO AL IGUAL QUE ULTRA Y EXCITER, LO RESCATABLE DE ESTE NUEVO DISCO ES QUE QUISIERON VOLVER UN POCO A LO INDUSTRIAL Y AL DARK, PERO CREO QUE ABUSARON DEMASIADO CON LOS SONIDITOS ANALOGOS Y DEMAS RUIDOS, LA MAYORIA DE LAS CANCIONES LLEGAN A ABURRIR ANTES DE ESCUCHARLAS COMPLETAMENTE, ES UN DISCO FLOJO. <br />CUANDO ESCUCHE EL PRIMER TRACK, SI ME MOVIO UN POCO Y PENSE QUE TOMARIA UN BUEN RUMBO, PERO DESPUES LLEGA JOHN THE REVELATOR Y LA MAGIA SE ACABA. <br />SIGO PENSANDO QUE EL PROBLEMA SIGUE SIENDO LA AUSENCIA DE ALAN WILDER Y SU OBSESION POR LA TECNICA Y LA PRODUCCION LA CUAL LE DABA ESE TOQUE TAN PERFECTO Y FINO A LOS DISCOS DE DEPECHE MODE, QUE SI BIEN ES CIERTO QUE MARTIN GORE COMPONE, ALAN WILDER LAS PULIA Y LES DABA EL SONIDO ADECUADO A UN ALBUM COMPLETO. <br />CREO QUE LOS UNICOS TRACKS RESCATABLES APARTE DE PRECIOUS (NO ME PUEDO IMAGINAR TODAVIA CUAL SERA EL PROXIMO SENCILLO PORQUE NO HAY NINGUNA QUE LO AMERITE) SON: A PAIN THAT I'M USED TO,  SINNER IN ME, NOTHING'S IMPOSSIBLE(LOS PRIMEROS 3 MINUTOS , DESPUES SE VUELVE ABURRIDO). <br />Y ABURRIDO EN SI ES TODO EL ALBUM, NO POR FALTA DE TALENTO NI DE IDEAS, ES LA PRODUCCION DEL DISCO LO QUE LE DA EL SONIDO FINAL Y ESTA VEZ VUELVEN A FALLAR, NO ES JUSTO QUE DESPUES DE 4 AOS DEPECHE MODE NOS VUELVA A OFRECER UN DISCO CASI MEDIOCRE. <br />CREO QUE ESTE DEBE SER EL ULTIMO DISCO DE DEPECHE Y POR SALUD MENTAL ES LO QUE DEBEN DE HACER A MENOS DE QUE ALAN WILDER REGRESARA Y LE AYUDE A MARTIN A PULIR SUS IDEAS, ENTONCES SI NOS VOLVERIAN SORPRENDER COMO SOLIA SER ANTES.
B000001GLK|5.0|This is how the Beethoven concertos should be played - with majesty and grandeur. After buying this Pollini recording, I find other recordings lacking in these aspects. If you are going to buy one recording of the concertos, this should be it. The live aspect, I think, is not really noticeable. Maybe one or two audience coughs but that is to be expected. These interpretations of Pollini are too good to turn down based on the fact that it's a live recording. This set includes the DEFINITIVE recording of the 4th Concerto. I challenge anyone to find a better performance. Pollini knows Beethoven, trust me. I've listened to over 20 different interpretations and in my opinion Pollini's performances here come the closest to the composer's intentions. The Berlin Philharmonic does an excellent job with the accompaninent as well. Not to be missed!

B0000C8AV3|4.0|Infidels took me a few listens to fully appreciate, but now I really love it and listen to it often. Of course, it doesn't compare to the heights of Blood on the Tracks or Desire, nor is it as stunning as the subsequent Oh Mercy, but it is a fine album that makes a very enjoyable listen. Right from the opening song, the excellent Jokerman, you realize that this is going to be a bit different from Dylan's usual sound. However, Dylan has reinvented his sound so many times that he really can't be said to have a distinctive sound. With its Caribbean rhythm, Jokerman is a distinctive song in Dylan's oeuvre. I particularly like that little bass thing right before the chorus kicks in. Another thing I like about this album is the \\"rambling\\" songwriting style. On songs such as Jokerman, Dylan just seems to ramble on and on about these completely unrelated scenarios and you often have no clue what he's talking about. That's not a criticism though, I find it very interesting. You never know what he's going to talk about next. There is a bit of political content here, yes, but I really don't think of Infidels as a political album. I think it's more cynical than political. I think Dylan is basically saying that the world sucks, and he wishes to wash his hands of it. Whether or not this is from a religious perspective is debatable. There are certainly religious references here, but they're not blatant like on Slow Train Coming and Saved. To be honest, I'm not quite sure what most of these songs are about. A couple are pretty obvious, such as Union Sundown and License to Kill, but I don't have a clue as to what Jokerman or I and I are about. It's okay though, Dylan doesn't often spell out the meaning of his songs. The music is great with Dylan getting support from Dire Strait's Mark Knopfler and former Rolling Stone Mick Taylor. Just like on the earlier Slow Train Coming, Knopfler's guitar is a musical highlight of the album. The rhythm section consisting of Robbie Shakespeare and Sly Dunbar is very tight as well. Excellent bass and drum work.<br /><br />To get the complete picture, be sure to pick up The Bootleg Series Volume 1-3 which features several songs that were cut from the album. Those songs are just as good as the ones on the album, if not better. Particularly Blind Willie McTell, which any Dylan fan should hear as it is one of his finest songs. Foot of Pride and Lord Protect My Child are also great songs that were recorded for Infidels but left off. Of course, people will always say that Infidels would have been a much better album with these tracks included, but it's really pointless. Just appreciate the album for what it is, not for what it could have been. The missing tracks are all available now anyway so with the proper technology you could reconstruct the \\"better\\" version of the album if you so desire.<br /><br />Infidels is one of Dylan's best albums of the 1980s. The songs are memorable and the music is great, even though the drums sometimes have that annoying 80s echo that I dislike. The lyrics are potent, the band is great and Bob's singing is quite good, though his lovely '70s voice was gone by this point. I wouldn't recommend it to a beginner, but if you're looking to explore Dylan's later years, Infidels is a great album to check out.Sly Dunbar is very tight as well. Excellent bass and drum work.     To get the complete picture, be sure to pick up The Bootleg Series Volume 1-3 which features several songs that were cut from the album. Those songs are just as good as the ones on the album, if not better. Particularly Blind Willie McTell, which any Dylan fan should hear as it is one of his finest songs. Foot of Pride and Lord Protect My Child are also great songs that were recorded for Infidels but left off. Of course, people will always say that Infidels would have been a much better album with these tracks included, but it's really pointless. Just appreciate the album for what it is, not for what it could have been. The missing tracks are all available now anyway so with the proper technology you could reconstruct the \\"better\\" version of the album if you so desire.    Infidels is one of Dylan's best albums of the 1980s. The songs are memorable and the music is great, even though the drums sometimes have that annoying 80s echo that I dislike. The lyrics are potent, the band is great and Bob's singing is quite good, though his lovely '70s voice was gone by this point. I wouldn't recommend it to a beginner, but if you're looking to explore Dylan's later years, Infidels is a great album to check out.

The songs are memorable and the music is great, even though the drums sometimes have that annoying 80s echo that I dislike. The lyrics are potent, the band is great and Bob's singing is quite good, though his lovely '70s voice was gone by this point. I wouldn't recommend it to a beginner, but if you're looking to explore Dylan's later years, Infidels is a great album to check out.

B000B2YQX4|3.0|Following the after-hours ambience of the ironically-titled Exciter, Depeche Mode return with a distorted, industrial sound, recalling earlier classics like The Dead of Night, Barrel of a Gun, and I Feel You. Though the relaxed, down-tempo Exciter was a progression into new territory, Playing the Angel is a conscious retreat. This time Dave Gahan has managed to do what Alan Wilder never could, get more than 2 of his songs on a DM release, and--like Wilder's infrequent contributions--his material deserves to be heard. I liked DM better before they started making purely serious albums in the mid nineties. The best tracks here (Precious and Suffer Well) combine their emotional anguish with their innate dance-pop sensibilities, and should remind the band that they don't need to be heavy to be good.

B0001XAOLQ|5.0|\\"This is Lieutenent Werner, war correspondent.\\" So says the U-boat's Captain to his second officer, amidst all the noise of a nightclub, as the latter tries to steady himself at attention. \\"He'll ship out with us. He'll report the true facts---life on a submarine.\\"  And it's through these eyes, figuratively speaking (Lieut. Werner does not speak to us or speak over the film), that we are taken on a journey through the atlantic's stormy waters, and to its depths.  I've gone along for the ride over a dozens times thus far and have enjoyed this film with each viewing.  Concerning the 3 versions available: If you're having movie night with some friends and want an enjoyable action adventure---very realistic depth charge explosives rocking this German sub (as well as your living room, if you have a surround sound system especially) then the original version will suit you well.  This shortest version has a rather fast pace wherein something always is happening of a threatening nature, to either the sub itself or to the convoy freighters that the Germans are attempting to sink.  The director's cut, in contrast, is about 50% longer and, as such, has a somewhat slower pace; as does this complete uncut version that was initially broadcast in Germany as an almost 6 hour mini-series.  (Incidentially, the first 2 versions are simply edited versions of the latter one.)  Owing to its lenth, I can understand how one would prefer one of the abbreviated versions (and I sometimes watch the director's cut for this reason myself), but when I want to really get immersed (pardon the pun) in this story I reach for this uncut version.  For in this version it is far easier to feel aboard this sub as we watch the crew, like Lieutenent Werner does, with absorbing eyes; as they come alive to go on the attack, race to assume battle stations, rally in the face of death to save their craft when attacked themselves, or slumber/write/eat/sing/daydream of home.  And one gets a lot more of the latter activities in this uncut version, giving us the closest experience most of us will ever get of being aboard a submarine.  The lighting, the realism, the acting, the dialogue, the direction, you name it, everything about this film is consistantly superior to any other war film I've seen; and most other dramas as well.  It is, in short, one of the finest efforts presented on film.  I hope I have been of some help herein persuading you to consider seeing this motion picture in its full-lenth, most effective, form. (Unless you're 100% allergic to subtitles I recommend viewing the director's & uncut versions in the original German; and preferably on an otherwise quiet eve, in the dark, if you want to get the full import of this absorbing film.) Cheers!activities in this uncut version, giving us the closest experience most of us will ever get of being aboard a submarine. Cheers!

0452281881|5.0|The London arm of Millers Shanks, an international advertising agency, is trying to land the Coca-Cola account.  Through a series of e-mails, we get to see the entire process, including the in-house romances, the back-stabbing, the ineptness of some in upper management, the gossip.  Author Matt Beaumont has created a juicy and comic novel about life behind the scenes, and even more amazing, it's told completely via e-mail.  At first glance, you may think this would make the storytelling more difficult, but after a few pages, you pick up on personalities and quirks and soon forgetting that the book is a series of emails.  Wonderful characters, a great story, a fantastic novel.
0553296981|5.0|I have fallen in love with a girl named Anne Frank.<br /><br />It took me forty-some years to finally get to this book. Having now read it, I have been completely smitten by this vivacious, intelligent and strong young teenager.<br /><br />I understand this is the \\"uncut\\" version of the diary, including segments which reveal her burgeoning sexuality. I was taken aback by her candor, her insight, her ability to be impossibly self-aware.<br /><br />It begins shortly before her imprisonment in the \\"Secret Annexe\\", and ends so abruptly it's painful. Since you know what will happen to her, your anxiety level increases as you near the end of the book. I found myself still hoping for a rescue, even though I knew one would never come.<br /><br />Her optimism infused me to the point of irrationality.<br /><br />How fortunate for us that she is a natural writer. Her vivid descriptions of the Annexe, it's inhabitants, her own feelings...she has given us a window into a soul.<br /><br />Diaries are by necessity and definition intimate. They are NOT by necessity and definition \\"literature.\\"<br /><br />This diary happens to be exactly that. While technically the voice of one girl, one cannot help but see through her own words, the thoughts and feelings of an entire country. An entire religion.<br /><br />Being a young girl, a young Jew, during the rise of Hitler...NONE of us will ever know how that felt.<br /><br />By some miracle, by the fact that this diary exists, and was presented for all to read, we will always be able to at least come close to understanding the inexplicable horror of that era.<br /><br />All through the eyes of an amazing young girl.

0060931671|5.0|If you've tried to read Pynchon in the past, but never managed to wade through the sheer bulk of his insanity, this might be the book for you.  An excellent introduction to this justly lauded writer, it's not overlong at 160 pages (almost a novella, from Pynchon) and includes a very succinct summing up near the conclusion that safely resolves any doubts about what he's trying to say.  In fact, if this book has a major flaw, it could be that it's insufficiently subtle.  There may be those among Pynchon's admirers who feel that that they're being hit over the head with this book's philosophical issues, and may prefer those books where it isn't laid out quite so neatly for all to see.<br /><br />But many others will find a lot to like in this wildly comic, but deeply pointed novel.  Twenty-eight-year-old Oedipa Maas is appointed executrix of a deceased eccentric entrepreneur's will and suddenly finds herself abandoning her husband to live in a paranoid fantasy-world replete with secret societies, an  underground postal service, and the mysterious organization known as Tristero.  But is her fantasy reality?  Or vice versa?  As always in Pynchon's California, there's no shortage of binge drinking, casual sex, or wild parties, and a good time will be had by all readers who enjoy a good dose of chaos now and then.  The ending will disappoint some, but since there are no easy answers, surely this conclusion makes more sense than any mere pat ending could.

6305428387|5.0|This movie is based on the first Jamaican bobsled team, which competed in the 1988 Olympics.  What I enjoy most about this movie is how the team was initially treated as a joke by fellow Jamaicans and their country, and even each other, but slowly gained the respect of not only their own countrymen, but experienced bobsled teams from other countries.<br /><br />The movie begins when two people who expected to join the Jamaican Olympic team in track and field events lose because a fellow runner fell.  The only other option for Derrice Bannock (Leon, who has appeared in \\"All the Right Moves\\" in 1983, \\"Colors\\" in 1988, and is the innocent man in Madonna's video \\"Like a Prayer,\\" along with numerous other movies) is to form a bobsled team and travel to the winter Olympics.<br /><br />Derrice manages to form a ragtag team consisting of Sanka Coffie (Doug E. Doug), Junior Bevil (Rawle D. Lewis) and Yul Brenner (Malik Yoba).  Derrice also finds disgraced former coach Irving Blitzer (John Candy, in one of his final roles) and convinces him to train the team.<br /><br />The movie then follows the team as they train in Jamaica.  We also watch as family, friends and government officials do everything possible to discourage the team from pursuing their goal.  Even officials with the Olympics do their best to keep the team from entering the Olympics.<br /><br />As the movie progressed there was a point where I actually started to care about the characters, and I wanted the Jamaican team to do well against the established teams.  I supposed that my natural tendency to support underdogs took control here, but I was pleased that the Jamaicans more than competed; they competed and were holding their own.  I will leave it to the viewer to see what happens at the end.<br /><br />While this movie is funny, the humor is obtained with respect toward the characters.  Disney has had its ups and downs in recent years with movie quality, but I would consider this movie one of the ups.  There are a number of stereotypical portrayals, but this is a movie and Disney wanted to be very clear as to who the good guys and the bad guys were.<br /><br />This movie is one that you will want to watch more than once.  While the real Jamaican team that inspired this movie was lost in the humor and the drama created to make the movie entertaining, I believe you will enjoy the humor and the ending where, in traditional Disney style, everything works out in the end.s. B0009A40ES|5.0|If you own or saw tha original American Psycho, and liked it at all, immediately click Buy. The movie itself is a four star masterpiece, and we get a bevy of special features and an extended cut.<br /><br />Mary Harron directs and co-writes with Guinevere Turner, who writes and appears as Elizabeth in the movie. They adapted the screenplay off of the book by Bret Easton Ellis. They use the backdrop of the Eighties and the Yuppster-wave to create a social satire, surreal black comedy, and suspense horror all rolled into one fantastic movie.<br /><br /> Christian Bale plays Patrick Bateman, a yuppie who has all the right clothes, all the right friends (Bill Sage, Josh Lucas, Justin Theroux), a gorgeus fiancee (Reese Witherspoon as Evelyn), he's cheating on her with her best friend (Sam Mathis as Courtney), and is rising to the height of wallstreet celebrity. There's just one problem.... He has a lust to kill. Everyone.<br />The killer inside is someone he hides behind this mask of success and humanity. But he struggles to even be human. He longs for sex or violence, sometimes both. But when things start to get out of hand, he begins to lose his sanity, blending his perception of the monster within with the reality around him.<br /><br />Christian's performance is amazing, as we find out in the commentary that not only did he have an amazing and rigorous excercise regimen to get an amazing physique, but in some scenes when he is dealing with inspector Kimball (Dafoe) he actually sweats on cue. Anyone who has seen him in Batman Begins, The Machinist, Equilibrium, or Velvet Goldmine will know he is a modern master, always putting himself through intense preparations for his roles. The rest of the actors are great too, with their 80's parody and preppy accents. The only thing I thought needed more screen time was Willem Dafoe. He had plenty of time in the book, and he gets top billing, but he is hardly used in the movie.<br /><br />The movie does a really good job of an ambiguous ending and keeping the line between what Bateman is imagining, and whats actually happening. The scene where he is going on his rampage with the chainsaw, and the one with the gun, are so violent and over the top, that were not even sure why things are happening or if they even are. In the ending, were left with a sense that in a world where everyone strives to be the same, Bateman can't even be recognized as himself, even when he's trying to get caught. A scary and disturbed theme, that applies to more than the fictional world of Psycho, but seems as though it could have been a true story of the 80's and maybe even today.<br /><br />This is the 'uncut killer edition' so we're treated to some great specials features, in fact more (in a sense, more on that in a minute) than I've seen. The other editions had only a short making-of and a interview with Christian Bale. However, this edition gets 2 commentary tracks, Six deleted scenes, 3 making-of featurettes and behind-the-scenes/interviews. Also, and odd addition of an essay written by Holly Willis and read by singer Sarah Elquist.<br /><br />The first commentary features director/co-writer Mary Harron. She talks about the idea behind translating the book to screen, some of the happy accidents during shooting, the actors, etc. It's a good commentary that not only gives you info on the movie, and the controversary surrounding the book and movie. She follows the movie well and doesn't stop more than a couple times. The second track features Guinevere Turner, cowriter. She does not do such a good track speaking about her inspirations and what they changed and took out in reference to the book. But she really just watches the movie, and kinda complains.<br /><br />The 'Postcards from the 80's' featurettes are sort of a making-of crossed with the VH1 formula: A whole lot of critics and producers/crew and random celebrities talking about the three parts of getting the movie made; 'The Book', 'The Deal', 'The Film'.They also go quite in depth in these three bits about the controversy of the book, and later how that affected the movie. Also, there's another called, 'The 80's: Downtown'. It's a look at the nostalgia elements used in the film. Same idea as the others, random people including people involved in the movie.  Lastly, is 'The Violence of Pornography' essay. It looks at it's own social commentary from both sides. Something the films doesn't touch and not a lot of movies who would tell you the critique of it's content.<br /><br />Overall this disc is a great special release, and even if you already own the original, get this one. A great addition to horror fans or yuppie haters collections.e controversy of the book, and later how that affected the movie. Also, there's another called, 'The 80's: Downtown'. It's a look at the nostalgia elements used in the film. Same idea as the others, random people including people involved in the movie.  Lastly, is 'The Violence of Pornography' essay. It looks at it's own social commentary from both sides. Something the films doesn't touch and not a lot of movies who would tell you the critique of it's content.    Overall this disc is a great special release, and even if you already own the original, get this one. A great addition to horror fans or yuppie haters collections.

After her globe-trotting, uncaring mother gives her a rosary she got at a small church in Brazil, Frankie begins hallucinating, and becoming injured.  The doctors think these wounds were self-inflicted.<br /><br />Father Kiernan (Gabriel Byrne) is sent by the Vatican to investigate rumors of a woman with stigmata.  Kiernan is an investigator for the Catholic Church, documenting claims of bleeding statues and the like.  But Kiernan is frustrated when he realizes the Cardinal (Jonathan Pryce) only wants to put such rumours to bed, not to truly explore them.<br /><br />Kiernan and Frankie become close, which angers the Cardinal. 0140277447|4.0|I thought this book was absolutely gripping.  Having lived in Poland for several years and visited many of the Holocaust sites, it is easy to forget that this kind of planned, mass extermination has occured many times in history - far past and recent (though I would certainly not conclude the atrocity in Nanjing was even close to that of the Holocaust).  Still, it is hard not to draw parallels and differences between the two. By fate, I now live in China, and have taken an interest in learning more about this forgotten tragedy.<br /><br />The author I thought did a very good job detailing her facts and citing her references, though I need to admit that for the first 1/3 or so of the book I was starting to feel like it was a bit propagandish.  That doubt eventually subsided, and i found the last 1/2 of the book hard to put down.  I often went back to the horrific pictures - staked, beheaded, burned, brutally raped people - very sobering.<br /><br />It is interesting how this massacre has been widely forgotten, and the part of the book that deals with WHY it has been forgotten, is perhaps the most interesting.<br /><br />Still, the one downside of this book - if you compare it to ones like \\"Night\\" (Elie Wiesel), \\"The Pianist\\", etc. - is that the author was NOT a witness to the tragedy.  You cannot blame her for when she was born, but at the same time, I think it is unfortunate that the story is not told by a person who saw the atrocities with her own eyes.<br /><br />I would recommend this book to anyone interested in WWII, wartime aggression, crimes against humanity, or to learn something new that you probably had never heard of before.

Franze Kafka's Gregor Samsa also comes to mind in the novella, Metamorphosis, where he awakes one morning to find that he has transformed into a giant insect. All these characters move in and out of reality, as the line has blurred, existing in a world of sickness and suffering, struggling to attain some kind of insight, as to who they are and what is happening to them.<br /><br />The Machinist unfolds through the eyes of Reznik, a man who hasn't slept in a year, and whose only real friend is a prostitute, (Jennifer Jason Leigh) and as the story propels forward, the nightmare becomes more complicated, much more intense, as we the audience attempt to decipher Reznik's situation: are these hallucinations due to lack of sleep or something more sinister?<br /><br />A new character enters the scene - a dangerous looking man who claims to be working at Reznik's machine shop. B00005JOI3|5.0|It becomes apparent about  way through Marc Forster's (the persuasive \\"Monster's Ball\\" and the boring \\"Finding Neverland\\") \\"Stay\\" that things are not going to make much technical sense and because the beautiful images that he chooses to present are so seductive, I take a deep breath, relax and just let the movie flow over, around and through me.<br />\\"Stay\\" plays with time, perception and the chronology of events that may or may not have occurred. But as opposed to a film like the similarly structured \\"Momento,\\" in which the protagonist is so far removed from ours or anyone's reality, we make a connection, develop a relationship with the trio of Sam (Ewan McGregor), Lila (the impossibly beautiful Naomi Watts) and Henry (the scruffy, pale, skinny Ryan Gosling): a bond based on the empathy and sympathy of Forster's presentation of these characters.<br />Does everything make sense in \\"Stay?\\" No. Do we ultimately care if it makes 100% sense? No, again. \\"Stay\\" is like that beautiful, older, flirty cousin: you admire her, maybe even fall in love with her. You touch her if she let's you... but you can never have a real relationship with her: she is approachable but she can never be yours completely.<br />There are so many films today that never let you close, that keep you at arms length because they are empty, without a beating heart...devoid of any real emotion.<br />\\"Stay\\" grabs and scratches at your heart. It has the guts to be not completely clear about its intentions and its meaning. \\"Stay\\" is like the one night stand that you cannot completely forget...even years later.

B000AARKOO|3.0|I watched Kingdom of Heaven last night.  After so many reviews have already been written, I should save my time--having spent too much on this film as it is--but one scene cries out to me for comment.  It is a scene that speaks directly to what I think is the central flaw in the movie.    King Baldwin of Jerusalem is a leper.  Though he is young, the disease has ravaged his body to the extent that he fully swathes himself in fine silks and a silver mask.  Baldwin's humane treatment of the conquered Muslim people of his kingdom, our knowledge of his youth, the beauty of his costumes, the gentle body language of his poses, and the tender voice of actor Edward Norton all combine to make him a wonderfully sympathetic character.    Now to that one scene, which I maintain is symptomatic of the problem which pervades this movie.  As she gazes, in grief, at her brother's dead body-- shrouded, as he was in life--Sibylla reaches down and removes the mask.  Her character will never be the same for me:  she has previously promised her dying brother to remember him as he was as a beautiful boy.  Now she breaks a deathbed vow.  But the worst is to come:  the camera shows us that ghastly face in the coffin.  Now, I am disgusted, not by what I see in the coffin.  I am disgusted with Ridley Scott.  He has just destroyed the one graceful thing in this world of violence he has created.  Don't tell me that this is a philosophical decision:  \\"Scott wants to tell us that all is desolation.\\"  Balderdash!  If any movie ever had a Hollywood ending, this one does.   What Scott wants is to shock.  All in this movie is desolation until it's time to send everybody home with a smile.    Is there a single sword stroke in this movie that does not just draw blood, but arterial blood?  Blood that squirts a foot or two?  I realize that I exaggerate, but not by that much.  The movie begins with a beheading (we're spared this one), progresses to a man (a priest!) being simultaneously run through and burned to death, and culminates with thousands skewered, stoned, hacked, and boiled in oil and tar.  Are these merely realistic battle scenes at the service of historical fiction?  Well, partly.  The brutality may be as believable as any I've seen, though much I've seen (Branaugh's Henry V, for instance) is more artfully done, and thus, more effective; but the fiction is about as \\"historically\\" accurate as Uncle Remus.  That leaves us with Ridley Scott, the auteur of mayhem.  And he was such a fine and imaginative a director in Blade Runner.  I'm no prude when violence is concerned, but if you rip off the mask it had better be to some good purpose.    There's much more, of course.   From the first, when a priest steals a corpse's cross, to the last, when a bishop counsels Balian to convert to Islam and repent later, it isn't simply that the Christian Church is stereotyped as an evil monolith; every official representative of the Church who is characterized at all is evil.  One priest sounds disturbingly like a modern-day terrorist:  \\"To kill an infidel is not to commit murder.    It is the will of God.\\"  This is too familiar a litany to our ears, and too ironic, not to be intentional.  It is as heavy handed, and as ugly, as is the face in the coffin.       I haven't given this movie one star, as some have, since Jeromy Irons and Ghassan Massoud give excellent performances, Orlando Bloom--though miscast in the lead role of Balian--does his best and comes remarkably close to the heroic figure he should be, and the visual spectacle is sometimes enthralling.  When Balian leads his puny few against a Muslim army, the overhead shot makes it appear that the smaller force is being swallowed alive, and that's really all that needs to be said about the affair.  It's a much better piece of filmmaking than what is to follow.      For Balian is spared by the very man whose life he had spared much, much earlier.  You see, he had just survived a colossal shipwreck--the only human being to do so--and had washed up on the shores of Palestine.  He spared this man's life after killing his companion, a renowned fighter, in a sword fight.  (Balian hadn't known how to use a sword that long, himself.  Isn't that special?)  Now, (much, much later, mind you) Balian and the man he spared just happen to meet in the middle of a huge, tumultuous battlefield.  Right.  Not such believable film making.  By the way, at the end, with the army of Jerusalem gone off to its doom, where do Balian's peasant knights get all that armor for his very lackluster speech and the last battle at the gate?      What we need are not more directors who pander to the audience's thirst for blood and explosions.  We have enough of those.   What we need, and need  badly, are more directors who at least aspire to be like Branaugh.  We see the scurrilous murderers sneak behind the English lines in Henry V.  Later, we see the corpses of the slain boys who attend the English camp.  We don't have to witness their massacre; it's much better that we don't.  It occurs behind the mask.  We need more directors who aspire to be like Fred Zinnemann, directors who at least aspire to give us historical dramas like A Man for All Seasons, which ends with the most effective beheading in film history.  We only hear the thwack of the headsman's ax.  Sir Thomas's head falls--behind the mask.

B000B2YQX4|4.0|I have to admit, I was really psyched for Playing The Angel to come out after hearing Precious.  Their leadoff single is a Depeche Mode tour de force, encompassing all of the elements of a great DM single.  And I think that's partly why I initially felt some disappointment listening to the rest of the album.  While overall it's a very worthwhile CD, for the first time I didn't feel it had enough catchy and immediately accesible  songs.   <br /> <br />They've always tried to challenge themselves musically, but the best albums do so while hooking you in with catchy beats and memorable choruses.  It's why Violator (and really for me, all their CDs since Some Great Reward, including Exciter) is held in such esteem.  In Playing the Angel, I didn't consistently feel that way.  I had to sit and chew on the songs for a while before they grew on me.  That's never happened before for me.  <br /> <br />Keep in mind that this is not necessarily a bad thing.  And about 1/2-2/3 the CD is great.  Certainly, any DM album is going to be at least very good - they're too talented not to be.  But I keep comparing Playing The Angel to Exciter.  Contrary to popular opinion, I loved Exciter.  I thought Mark Bell's minimalist style fit the songs well.  And in my humble opinion, most of Exciter's songs are a little better PTA's songs.  Even Precious - I'm probably in the minority who thinks that Dream On is at least just as good, maybe even slightly better.  The second-tier songs of both CDs are about equal quality.   <br /> <br />But mainly the problem is that the worst songs on PTA are nowhere near as good as the worst songs on Exciter - specifically the vocal contributions of Martin.  He's a great songwriter - but his voice is really bad on PTA.  One of his songs is total dreck and he nearly ruins his other song.  I din't feel that way about Comatose or Breathe from Exciter.  I din't feel that way about Counterfeit 2 (another CD panned by most, which I personally think is very good).  But I do feel that way here.  Damaged People alone lowered PTA by 1/2 star. <br /> <br />Here's a rundown of my opinion on the rest of the songs: <br /> <br />A Pain That I'm Used To - 4/5 - a good opener - while the opening high pitched buzz sound still jars me as much as it did on Dead Of Night, I like the effective interplay between quiet verse and catchy chorus.  This one has grown on me from the first time I listened to it. <br /> <br />John The Revelator - 4.5/5 - very catchy, cool song.  Love the \\"Who's That Shouting?\\" call/response in the chorus.  Will make a good second single. <br /> <br />Suffer Well - 5/5 - the pleasant surprise of the CD!  While not as obviously great as Precious, it is sneakily effective - it truly shows Dave's conitnued growth as a songsmith.  This should be the third single - it has potential to do even better than Precious, kind of how on Violator, Enjoy the Silence charted higher than more obviously catchy Personal Jesus <br /> <br />The Sinner In Me - 4/5 - A slow one that has grown on me.  I especially like the guitar interplay at the end of the song. <br /> <br />Precious - 5/5 - the best song on the CD - a great single that harkens you back to the mid 80's style of DM.  The part of the second verse where they sing \\"if God has a Masterplan...\\" ,  with Martin in the background, followed by the chorus, is truly magical stuff. <br /> <br />Macrovision - 3.5/5 - the first one Martin sings.  I kind of like the song, the lyrics are cool, but Martin's voice is horrible and nearly ruins the song. <br /> <br />I Want It All - 4/5 - the 2nd Dave composition - I like it's torchy vibe - another one that's grown on me <br /> <br />Nothing's Impossible - 4/5 - the final Dave composition - another mid-tempo rocker with a sneakily effective chorus with cool keyboard schreeches and blips - would make a decent single <br /> <br />Introspective - 2/5 - an instrumental that is pretty nondescript and does nothing for me. <br /> <br />Damaged People -1/5 - Ugggh! is all I can say - The amazon reviewer is right about the showtuney vibe.  Skip this one every time. <br /> <br />Lilian - 4/5 - a nice bounceback - kind of throwaway, but I likle the beats and it's catchy. <br /> <br />The Darkest Star - 3/5 - the dubby 6-minute closer.  In reality, this one is just OK.  It could've been beter if it were more streamlined.  PTA probably deserved a better ending. <br /> <br />All in all, Playing The Angel starts off well, but trails off at the end.  I call it like it see it - it'll please the die-hards like myself, but it probably won't win too many new fans.  But hey - it's still Depeche Mode and you can never can wrong with that! <br /> <br />
B000001GS3|5.0|This is probably Deutsche Grammophone's greatest release. From a 70's LP, this remastered recording stars Piero Cappucilli and Shirley Verrett as Shakespeare's most wicked couple- Macbeth and Lady Macbeth. At a bargain price, this is a real treasure. It is on the top lists of the greatest opera recordings ever made. Shirley Verrett is still hailed as the ultimate Lady Macbeth. Upon performing the role in La Scala for the first time, she was showered in jewels and carried over the shoulders of ecstatic fans to her limousine. As a bonus, this recording features Placido Domingo in the minor role of Macduff and Nicolai Ghiurov as the ghost of Banquo. Claudio Abbado, an Italian conductor, understands the complexity of the score but does not sacrifice melodic richness and the mix of sprightliness and ominious grandeur found within the score. <br /> <br />Piero and Shirley are on fire as Mr. and Mrs. Macbeth! Their scenes are full of fire and dramatic heft, their voices soar above the orchestra's fortissimi and they each provide a kind of dark, tragic granduer to their roles. Very few singers match their level of expertise. Perhaps only Leonard Warren and Leonie Rysanek in an earlier Metropolitan Opera performance equalled them in success. Cappucilli has a dark, edgy voice and even reminds me of Samuel Ramey, whom to my knowledge has not sung Macbeth but would sound a lot like Cappucilli. Furthermore, Cappucilli died recently and this is a tribute to his great artistry. Miss Verrett is awesome, and her renditions of \\"Vieni T'afretta,\\" \\"La Luce Langue\\" and the Sleeping Walking Scene are among the best, ranking with Maria Callas, Leonie Rysanek, Birgit Nilsson, Elena Soliotis and Carol Vaness. Verrett claims she was initially afraid to get into such a dark frame of mind for the role but her voice is perfectly suited for this character, despite her origins as a mezzo. It is her Lady Macbeth that most people recall with fondness, eventhough Grace Bumbry, too, sang the role inSalzburg early in her career in 1964. However, I favor Verrett's Lady Macbeth over Bumbry's. Without a doubt this is a terrific Macbeth and you won't regret buying it. It is truly the definative version while others pale in comparison.
B0009I7NNA|3.0|I spent a few weeks in California this last summer with a cousin. He's very much into the hardcore screamo scene, and essentially introduced me to the genre, as well as a number of prominent local and nationally known bands. One night we were at a music store browsing when I came across Waking the Fallen. I recognized the artist name, having previously heard them mentioned by a friend of mine back home, so I asked my cousin about them. He told me they were a very popular band, and that the album would certainly be worth buying. I bought the album.  <br /> <br />This was my first introduction to Avenged Sevenfold. Waking the Fallen stunned me, and I quickly purchased Sounding the Seventh Trumpet, which was just as satisfying. Naturally, when I heard their plans to release City of Evil, I didn't hesitate to get my copy.  <br /> <br />To my delight, the first track, Beast and the Harlot, proved to be exactly what I had expected from my previous experiences with the band. The song had a fierce, epic tone, and I immediatley recognized the scripture passage the lyrics had been derived from, and found the song to be a fitting rendition of the fall of Babylon. Burn It Down followed, and I was thrilled. Despite the absence of screaming, the band had managed to preserve its distinctly metalcore sound while obviously progressing both musically and talent-wise. I confess I never made it through Blinded In Chains. My listening session was interrupted, and when I resumed it the song just didn't have the same potent, driving sound I had come to expect. Bat Country, which I had already heard on the radio, struck me as surprisingly \\"glam\\" for the band, which disappointed me. Trashed And Scattered is catchy and a good song musically, but it took me some time to realize it, because I was so dispapointed by the lyrics. They were no where near the bar set by songs on previous albums, like Unholy Confessions and Reminissions. From there City of Evil took a turn for the worse, diving face-first into weak acoustic melodies that didn't even begin to interest me. I bought the album because I wanted the potent, forceful metal sound. I appreciate that the band probably wanted to try a different style for once, but half the album is really just boring. Long songs were an A7X trademark on Waking the Fallen, but here they just refuse to end. Songs like Sidewinder and The Wicked End had great potential, if only they'd picked up after that first minute of acoustics. The only other song on the album I enjoyed after that was Betrayed, which I honestly enjoyed.  <br /> <br />However, the thing that disppointed me most about City of Evil was that outside of Beast and the Harlot, the album completely lacked the eipc, zealous, and decisive tone, both lyrically and musically, that made Sounding the Seventh Trumpet and Waking the Fallen a true pleasure to listen to. Their songs are no longer morbid hymns to retribution and righteousness, and that's really where City of Evil fails as a continuation to Avenged Sevenfold's saga.
B00000DF6O|5.0|I never once thought, when I ordered this, that this might be as good as it is. Who would have thought that a 74 year old man, who has made dozens of records over a period of over 50 years, would put out something as vital and impressive as anything he's ever done. He says in the booklet that he went back to the basics on this album with everything recorded live (no overdubs), in a relaxed atmosphere, and backed by possibly the best band he's ever had. The results are awesome. To top it all off, the recording is top notch; The sound quality matches the performance - Super!
