B000AARKOO|3.0|Hollywood movies have never had the reputation to be historically accurate, and this movie, portraying the events surrounding the retaking of Jerusalem by the armies of Saladin, is no different. If one reads in some detail the many historical works on the Crusades (specifically the English translations) one easily sees these inaccuracies. However, the movie does respect much of the historical record, depending of course on the historian(s) one wishes to consult. It is difficult to understand why Hollywood cannot make a movie that respects totally the true history, even given the pressures it feels to entertain the viewer.<br /><br />The movie's characters revolve around the following historical figures:<br /><br />Balian II of Ibelin: leader of Frankish resistance in Jerusalem in 1187. The real Balian was not a blacksmith and was married to Maria Comnena and was born in Jerusalem. According to some historians, Balian was an aggressive, even desperate, defender of Jerusalem, and the movie portrays him to be the same. His wife Maria (not portrayed in the movie) however alienated the Greek inhabitants of Jerusalem, who were already labeled as `heretics' by the Frankish Christians, and who were described by some historians as wishing for a Saladin victory.<br /><br />King Baldwin IV: the \\"Leper King\\", who ruled Jerusalem from 1174 to 1185. Some historians portray Baldwin IV as intelligent and as tenacious, and it is also an interesting fact that Baldwin IV was a leper from earliest childhood, but was still able to obtain the crown of Jerusalem. One can only speculate what would have happened if Baldwin IV had lived years longer than what he did. The jockeying for power after his death no doubt contributed a lot of instability and uncertainty in Jerusalem, making it easier for Saladin to retake it.<br /><br />Reynald of Chatillon: Prince of Antioch from 1153 - 1160 and lord of Kerak of Moab from 1177 - 1187. Reynald's behavior has been described by some historians as provoking Saladin into a conflict, and this behavior is reflected in the movie. Somewhat contrary to the content of the movie however, Baldwin IV entrusted Reynald with the command of the troops of Jerusalem, but they were defeated in the desert by the armies of Saladin.<br /><br />Saladin Yusuf: Sultan from 1174 - 1193. Saladin was leader of the Muslim army that finally took Jerusalem back from the Christians in the summer of 1187. His character has been given mixed reviews by the historians of the Crusades, being portrayed as a brutal and fanatical Muslim by some and as a conqueror that did not abuse his power by others.<br /><br />Saladin and Balian are both portrayed as somewhat calm, rational figures in the movie, contrary to what some historians say about them. Saladin did not let the inhabitants go as was portrayed in the movie. According to a few historians, this is inaccurate, as most were sold into slavery. Other historians though paint a different picture of Saladin, portraying him as being very kind and merciful, to be contrasted with the brutality of the Christian invaders of the First Crusade eighty-eight years earlier.  Under an agreement with Saladin, Balian tried to raise ransom money for thousands of the poor inhabitants of Jerusalem, but was unable to, primarily due to the stinginess of the churches of Jerusalem. Those inhabitants that were not ransomed were sold into slavery by the Muslims.  It is true however that Saladin refrained from slaughtering the Christian inhabitants of Jerusalem due to Balian's threat to destroy Jerusalem and murder its Muslim inhabitants. In addition, after retaking Jerusalem, Saladin refused to destroy the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, even though he was advised to do so by his lieutenants. The Knights Templar were not allowed access to the Mosque of al-Aqsa however, as Saladin restricted it to the Muslim faith.<br /><br />The real battles were a lot bloodier than even this movie portrayed them, even considering the hundreds of corpses lying in the desert being eaten by scavenging birds. The movie though was accurate in its portrayal of the condition of the armies of Jerusalem, with some historians describing it as being crowded with refugees and there being only two knights in the entire city.<br /><br />The success of Saladin's armies in retaking Jerusalem from the Christians provoked the Third Crusade. The movie ends with Richard the Lionhearted (Richard Coeur-de-Lion) and king of England, making his way to Jerusalem.<br /><br />It is fair to say that the director wants to play a conciliatory role between the Christian and Muslim faiths. One can be sympathetic with this goal, but a distortion of history never truly benefits anyone, despite the best of intentions. The invasion of Jerusalem by the Muslim armies of the eighth century were brutal and immoral acts, as were the invasions of the First Crusade and also the retaking of Jerusalem by Saladin's armies. The historical events must be seen and accepted as they are, and not used to justify a particular religious worldview or political ideology. Hollywood directors and screenwriters grant themselves the right to distort or falsify history in order to produce more satisfying entertainment. Historians have granted themselves the right to distort or falsify history for various reasons of their own. Which one of these groups is the most honorable? Which one causes the least damage to society?ven considering the hundreds of corpses lying in the desert being eaten by scavenging birds. The movie though was accurate in its portrayal of the condition of the armies of Jerusalem, with some historians describing it as being crowded with refugees and there being only two knights in the entire city.  <br /> <br />The success of Saladin's armies in retaking Jerusalem from the Christians provoked the Third Crusade. The movie ends with Richard the Lionhearted (Richard Coeur-de-Lion) and king of England, making his way to Jerusalem.  <br /> <br />It is fair to say that the director wants to play a conciliatory role between the Christian and Muslim faiths. One can be sympathetic with this goal, but a distortion of history never truly benefits anyone, despite the best of intentions. The invasion of Jerusalem by the Muslim armies of the eighth century were brutal and immoral acts, as were the invasions of the First Crusade and also the retaking of Jerusalem by Saladin's armies. The historical events must be seen and accepted as they are, and not used to justify a particular religious worldview or political ideology. Hollywood directors and screenwriters grant themselves the right to distort or falsify history in order to produce more satisfying entertainment. Historians have granted themselves the right to distort or falsify history for various reasons of their own. Which one of these groups is the most honorable? Which one causes the least damage to society?
B00005JMJ4|5.0|If you've ever been in a hotel in a strange city, lonely and unable to sleep, you will instantly identify with Bob Harris (Bill Murray), even though Harris is a well-heeled star and you probably are not. But don't go into this film expecting the plot to follow cliches. Harris is a prisoner in a 5-star palace, dealing with a difficult wife back home, and running into nubile, much younger Charlotte (Scarlett Johansson). You'd expect she and Harris and to have a sexual liaison. They do not, and the plot and script avoid a dozen other cliches.<br /><br />Instead, the story takes Harris and Charlotte down unexpected Tokyo alleys while the two try and sort out their lives.<br /><br />This film is directed with an eye to a stylistic capture of the reality of modern Japan. Bolstered by impressive cinematography (especially lighting and camera angles), it keeps the viewer interested and engaged as Murray and Johansson deliver consummate performances. Indeed, this is by far Bill Murray's finest work. Instead of the over-the-top characters in everything from \\"Scrooged\\" to \\"Ghostbusters,\\" we see an actor with depth of voice, emotion, and facial expression.<br /><br />Sophia Coppola knows her subject, having spent several years in Japan. Perhaps she could have been a bit tighter with the editing, but there is little else bad to be said about this film. Of course, this isn't a film for the action-movie, dramatic-effects crowd. But if you are the sort who enjoys \\"slice of life,\\" good dialogue, and a touching tale, well, order it now!

B000B2YQX4|4.0|Their finest in over a decade, or something like that. <br /> <br />Most fans hated Depeche Mode's last album, Exciter, with a passion. It wasn't dark. It wasn't melodramatic. It displayed Depeche Mode for what they really are: a group of comfortable, 40-something family men who make music on the side. Exciter was a mature, comfortable record with grown-up themes and a soft musical palette. I loved it. <br /> <br />Playing the Angel returns the band to a more lyrically and musically tumultuous place. It's their darkest album since at least Ultra, if not Music for the Masses. And it actually resembles a strange hybrid of those two albums more than anything else in their catalogue. The early press would have had us believe that this album was the second helping of Violator. While the band increasingly acknowledges that that album is their high-water mark, they also increasingly drop hints that they are not in the form to release an album that is end-to-end flawless again. That said, Playing the Angel is an excellent Depeche Mode album, and it's probably as good as they'll ever be without Alan Wilder. (They continue their streak of career-defining albums started 20 years ago with Black Celebration.)  <br /> <br />This album marks the return of dance to their catalogue. For at least ten years, the band has left it up to remixers to shape their tunes into beat-oriented club fare. Here, there's a churning rhythm almost everywhere you turn. They haven't sounded this young since 1987's dance-floor classic, Music for the Masses. This album seems to meld a \\"Behind the Wheel\\" pump with \\"Pimpf\\"'s cacophony. <br /> <br />The only thing missing here is weighty lyrics. Depeche Mode is best when they deliver songs that marry teen-angst to the adult world of emotions. Here, they seem somehow stuck in the melodrama. \\"Damaged People\\" is a good example. It's a beautiful track, but it forces the S&M parlor games of yore. On the other hand, it works for the album in much the way that \\"World Full of Nothing\\" did on Black Celebration. <br /> <br />The best songs here will hold up to DM's best. \\"John The Revelator,\\" \\"Suffer Well,\\" \\"Precious\\" and \\"Lillian\\" are textbook Depeche Mode. They swing and slide in and out of gospel, blues and dance, and they take their time through snaky key changes to do it. It should be said that Playing the Angel is also one of their most bizarre albums. The blistering electronics take time to get used to, but always fit the songs. I'm truly surprised at how the abrasive \\"Sinner in Me\\" and \\"Darkest Star\\" have grown on me.  <br /> <br />It might as well be 1988, folks. Depeche Mode hasn't sounded this bold and vibrant since about that time. True, there's no jaw-dropping, end-all, be-all single like \\"Enjoy the Silence,\\" \\"Personal Jesus,\\" or \\"Strangelove.\\" But what we've got is an album that plays like a throwback yet sounds fresh and vital. <br />It's not Violator (what could be?) but I'll take it. <br />

B00005ASGG|4.0|<br />John Ford's magnificent portrait of the lawless old west, THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE (1962), stars James Stewart as lawyer Rance Stoddard, Vera Miles as his wife Hallie, John Wayne as rancher Tom Donophon, and Lee Marvin as Liberty Valance, the meanest and nastiest outlaw in the frontier town of Shinbone.  Originally dismissed as just another John Wayne western, LIBERTY VALANCE is now considered a masterpiece of the genre. <br /> <br />The plot is simple:  Stoddard and Donophon join forces to kill Valance and his men on the night streets of Shinbone outside of the saloon.  But when and how?  Rounding out the cast is Ford's superb repertory of character actors:  Andy Devine as a marshall, Edmond O'Brien as a news editor, Ken Murray as a drunken doctor, John Qualen as a cook, and Woody Strode as a kitchen helper whose being black is never mentioned.  Ford is very hard on fair treatment of women (though Vera Miles is outstanding here), but he at least treats African-Americans with respect. <br /> <br />LIBERTY VALANCE is set in a long ago frontier town, with flawless art direction that includes stagecoaches and horse-drawn carriages.  One can smell the whiskey in the saloon and the sawdust on the wood-planked sidewalks.  And the movie has gorgeous B&W photography by William Clothier, who photographed several other Ford movies.  Most of the characters are complex, neither good nor bad.  The exception, of course, is Lee Marvin.  He makes Liberty Valance so vividly cruel and nasty that I needed reassurance that the actor is really dead in actual life!  The character is that real!  Stewart and Wayne are both in peak form.  They both had a great year in 1962, with this and HOW THE WEST WAS WON. <br /> <br />THE MAN WHO SHOT LIBERTY VALANCE, a serious and thoughtful adult western, is on DVD in the cheap $11.00 range as part of a John Wayne Signature Collection from Paramount Home Video.  I recommend you build your Wayne DVD collection with these studio print titles, also including THE SHOOTIST, THE COWBOYS, EL DORADO, HONDO, and the wide-screen debut of McLINTOCK!  (REVIEWED ON WIDESCREEN DVD.) <br /> <br />   <br />

0471267554|4.0|I think this is a good book on diet and nutrition and culture. The author is correct, I think, to criticize the typical U.S. diet, which is literally killing millions of people, because it is heavily based on sugar, carbohydrates, fat, and sodium (salt). Processed foods are full of bad things like hydrogenated fats, and fast food has all kinds of bad things in it. I also think that the idea of eating lean protein, fruits and vegetables is a very good idea. For example, you can literally eat as much fruit as you want. By the time your stomache is full, you will stop eating, but the energy density to volume of food is very low, so you won't gain weight. I think one big factor in the U.S. obesity epidemic is lack of exercise and movement (driving everywhere) and also the fact that portions keep increasing in size. Going to a lean protein and fruit and veggies diet is a good idea, because protein make you feel full far longer than carbs do. So in essence, I like this book and will do this diet. However, I mean, let's get real, the average paleolithic man or woman lived probably to be about 22 on average, whereas we today live to be 74. Paleo man died probably mostly of infections and parasites. He did not live long enough to develop heart disease or the types of diseases the author associates with our \\"high carb diet\\". So it is a bit of an unfair comparison. I would take our modern lifestyle over that of paleo man any day of the week, and I think it is a bit odd to hold up as a model a people that died so young. Another issue I have is, if our genetic code designs us for eating lean protein and veggies, why do the things we crave tend to be other things (donuts, pizza, etc.). If my genes are specifically built for eating veggies and lean protein, why do I like pizza and donuts more ? It can't all be \\"cultural factors\\". I once read an interview of a top European nutrition expert, and he said, they did research on what is in uncooked vegetables, and he reported that manyof the things are very harmful. Brocholi has some really nasty substances in it ! He also said that we should tune more into what our body tells us, because it doesn't lie. For example, you body self-regulates, and will give you signals for what to eat and when, if you know how to listen to it. So the idea in the Paleo diet that uncooked veggies are all good and that we are genetically designed to eat them and lean protein makes me wonder a bit, because moms all over the world have to force their kids to eat stuff like brocholi. Maybe nature knows a lot more than we do, and those kids are right, if they listen to what their body is telling them. I think the truth is, our paleo genetics doesn't know we live in an environment of extremely easy access to food (especially in the U.S.), and we tend to love fats and sugars and salt because in a resource-scare environment, we HAD to love them, because they were so rare. On the other hand, veggies were everywhere. So I think there are some very good concepts in this book, and everyone should think this through. It is fascinating and I appreciate that the author wrote this book, because it puts us on the right track.

The disintergration of the orignal lineup in early 1979 caused Sabbath to rethink their direction after Iommi had started to work with one Ronald Padonova aka Ronnie James Dio, who had recently left Ritchie Blackmore's Rainbow. Butler and Ward soon returned to the fold and a \\"new\\" Sabbath was born, streamlined for the NWOBHM generation. Faster more upbeat songs with Iommi's trademark menace and a new twist, Butler as longtime lyricist was out, Dio created or recreated the demons and wizards Sabbath. Dio is without a doubt Black Sabbath's greatest singer, operatic range, dynamics, flawless. Notice I said singer, not frontman because Ozzy will always be Sabbath's and one of rock's greatest showman. But Oz never had the chops and Dio kicks the band in the ass with his forceful direction. \\"Neon Knights\\" is an alltime barnburner, fantastic imagery and powerful metal, protectors of the realm indeed! \\"Heaven and Hell\\" has one of the greatest opening lines in the history of rock. But a lot of what Diamond writes about here seems mostly to be derivative.

B000BSZ0SI|5.0|I bought this CD about 15 years ago when it was readily available in the US, and find it both bloodcurtling and disturbing.  Richard Strauss bordered on atonality in parts of \\"Elektra\\" and the disturbing shrieks from the orchestra and singers underline the elements of madness in Elektra's character part.  Inge Borke, whom I confess to know little about, was a good choice on conductor Karl Bohm's part for the title role of this opera.  She seems mad almost throughout the opera with moments of calm and sanity in the inner parts of the score. <br /> <br />For those of you who aren't familiar with this music, read the title again.  It is disturbing!  It is not the comfortable sounds of Mozart, as in \\"The Marriage of Figaro\\" or Rossini's \\"The Barber of Seville.\\"  This is 20th century music, and compositionally conservative Richard Strauss's most bold, daring, disturbing and dissonant piece, worlds away from \\"Der Rosenkavalier.\\" <br /> <br />The Dresden State Orchestra is of course terrific under Bohm's baton, and although there are some out of tune woodwind parts in the middle pages of the score, the intensity and flow is so great, who cares?  Karl Bohm (1894-1981) was authoritative in Richard Strauss's operas and orchestral works, having been a personal friend of the composer from the early 1930s until Strauss's death in 1949. <br /> <br />The opera lasts about 100 minutes, so is not as long as some of the more famous operas in the repertory.  \\"Elektra\\" is set in ancient Greece, and the whole atmosphere is gloomy, unsettled, and depressing.  Don't listen to this if you're down, having a bad day, or need a lift.  It's the aural parallel of a Goya painting: bold and shocking.  <br /> <br />Karl Bohm recorded a film version of Elektra in 1981: it was his last project, and he died before it's release.  This will be released on DG DVD on November, and I look forward to seeing/hearing it.  The DVD has Leonie Rysanek and Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau (he's also in this recording) among the cast. Seeing \\"Elektra\\" as well as hearing it will be equally disturbing as this recording.
0441012906|3.0|I was reading through a list of \\"who's reading what\\", and I saw that the head of Amazon was reading Century Rain by Alastair Reynolds. Verity Auger is an archeologist who specializes in bringing back remains from the planet, and now the authorities need her help in figuring out a mystery...  as in what happened to one of their agents who traveled back in time via a wormhole in space, and ended up murdered.  The problem is that her few belongings seem to point to some catastrophe in the making, and no one knows what she was on to before she got killed.  Auger reluctantly goes on the mission, and meets up with a person from the past who is also trying to solve the mystery.  He doesn't know he's living in a \\"backup\\" of earth, and she doesn't want to tell him.  That all comes to an end when the Slashers infiltrate the past in order to get the murdered agents clues, and Auger and her friend need to escape via a collapsing wormhole in time to prevent *his* world from meeting the same fate as the present-day earth.<br /><br />The premise held some promise, and I started into the book expecting to get absorbed rather quickly.  But way too much time was spent in the past world, bringing the detective up to the point where Auger gets injected into the story. And even after it was all done, I was sort of left wondering if the time I spent had been worth it.<br /><br />Perhaps others will like it, as it's not a *bad* novel.  It just didn't grab hold and captivate me like I was hoping for...l.  It just didn't grab hold and captivate me like I was hoping for...

B0001ZX0OW|5.0|\\"Mystic River\\" definitely falls in the category of \\"character-driven\\" film.  It succeeds brilliantly, and is a benchmark for movies where character and not plot take center stage.<br /><br />First, you must have a plot, even if it's not the centerpiece of the movie.  Too many \\"character-based\\" dramas are meandering messes that go nowhere.  In contrast, \\"Mystic River\\" has enough of a plot to keep things moving, and it's interesting.<br /><br />Second, you must have a good script.  Oftentimes \\"character-driven\\" movies are tedious at best, because the characters have nothing to say.  Here, the screenwriter really created some memorable characters and great dialogue.  I am sure that Robbins, Bacon and Penn had a lot to do with that, too.<br /><br />That leads into point three - you must have great actors to breathe life into your characters, when your characters are your movie.  Robbins, Bacon and Penn have never been better, and each do a fantastic job.  Their performances are engrossing, and keep the film from dragging.<br /><br />Highly recommended.

0060512806|4.0|It would be hard for somebody who hasn't read this book to gain a decent understanding of it just by reading the reviews and summaries found here.  If you want to understand what this book is about, read it.  The scope of it is far too wide for anyone to generalize it.  That being said, I'll give it my best shot. <br /> <br />Cryptonomicon is long and arduous. It's more of an epic than anything I've ever read, including the epic poem \\"The Odyssey.\\"  It takes more than a modicum of effort to finish AND understand it.  I still don't believe I got everything out of it that Stephenson intended but I'm happy with the end result.  If you're not a mathematician or computer whiz, there are substantial parts of the book that will at the least bore you, and at the most make you feel stupid.  Stephenson delves into such areas like number theory, the Riemann Hypothesis, cryptography and Information Security for 20-30 pages at certain points.  One can certainly understand the book without being knowledgable in these areas, but those that have studied them will be rewarded with some insightful discussion.  The story itself is very unique and entertaining.  There are, of course, some parts that are more interesting and exciting than others but each one contributes to the overall effect of the book.  What the plot boils down to is this: Randy Waterhouse is a computer geek living in the present.  He is part owner of a company called Epiphyte Corp.  Randy's grandfather, Lawrence Pritchard Waterhouse, was a code-breaker for the Allies during WWII, working mainly on codes emanating from the Eastern part of the world.  Bobby Shaftoe is part of a classified Army unit whose sole purpose is to hunt down Nazi U-boats and ships and sink them.  Amy Shaftoe is the grand-daughter of Bobby Shaftoe and owner of a marine excavation company in the Phillipines.  She joins forces with Randy Waterhouse to build a free \\"data haven\\" in the Phillipines that would revolutionize the way we use computers.Goto Dengo is a Japanese soldier with a skill for digging big holes.  Enoch Root is an enigmatic priest with an obscure past and a unique relationship to every other character in the book. Eventually all of these peoples' stories merge in the Phillipines because of some Nazi gold that may or may not be there and the reader discovers why Stephenson went to such great lengths earlier in the book to describe certain details. <br /> <br />The only thing about this book that I have a problem with is the ending.  It's not bad but I felt that the author could have rewarded the reader with a little more after the reader endured 1100+ pages to get to that point.  It doesn't leave anything unanswered but it does leave a little to be desired.  However, those may just be my feelings of despair after actually finishing the book.

0226039331|5.0|I actually use the BDAG 3rd Edition add on in BibleWorks 7.0 along with Kittel's TDNT and Spicq's Theological Lexicon book sets.  In my software I have BDAG next to Thayer's, Liddell & Scott, Louw & Nida's Semantical Domain, United Bible Societies, and Friberg's Lexicon.  I use all of them every week for sermon exegesis (except for Kittel's and Spicq's).  BDAG is a great lexicon, maybe not the best...as some reviewers have said.  It really depends on what you are studying.  Louw & Nida's Semantical domain really helps one see the range of a word in context to other words, and BDAG doesn't do that.  BDAG gives one a lot of information, but if you are not a trained scholar, it's hard to understand it all.  So often I end up turning to other lexicons for more information.<br /><br />There is a tendency with BDAG towards gender inclusivity in some entries, so if you are concerned about that issue, you may be happy or unhappy with that depending on your position.  It's more accurate than the older editions.  Just know that the gender inclusive approach is controversial  and a reason why this lexicon should be compared with others. I really like to compare this lexicon with the semantical domain lexicon by Louw & Nida.<br /><br />Comparing this lexicon with other lexicons is super easy in the outstanding professional grade exegetical software called BibleWorks 6.0. (See my review there).  With the pass of mouse, one can see all the lexicons on a word, with BDAG being just one of several.  This allows constant comparison...and that's really the best way to use this lexicon in my opinion.  When you do that over and over, week after week, month after month as I do, one gets the feel for this lexicon's strength.  That strength is in providing good categories for a word, citing prime examples of each category, and a relatively fair approach in controversial issues.<br /><br />A nice improvement has been hyperlinks that allow one to click on BDAG citations to see their fuller context in the program.  I don't think I would get the book copy of this lexicon because the software version allows you to quickly paste an entry next to other lexicons in a word document and print them out for further ease of study and note taking.  How easy is that with a printed copy of the lexicon?<br /><br />With a program like BibleWorks 7.0 or their competitors one can search the lemma of a word instantly to see other instances of the use/form/stem which BDAG may not mention and get a graphical analysis of useage throughout various LXX/NT writers so you can assess the word in a more general way.<br /><br />Overall, BDAG turns out to be very helpful in providing a base to chase down more information on the nuance of a word's meaning for certain situations/contexts.  I cannot imagine doing exegesis without it.  I would only recommend you stick the $140 bucks into software that has BDAG as an add-on.  It's worth the extra money.<br /><br />2009 update to this review: I've found some bias in this lexicon. I've learned that one must double check the work, and have come to see more of this lexicon as a 'commentary' than as unbiased lexical data. For example, the word 'PROGINOSKO' (to foreknow) is defined in Thayer's lexicon simply as to foreknow, yet in BDAG it has two definitions: To foreknow AND also to choose beforehand. This second definition is then leaned on heavily by Calvinists to argue for Unconditional Eternal Election based in part on the two appearances of 'Proginosko' in Romans (8:29 is the classic example). The problem with this second definition is that the term 'Proginosko' is NEVER used to mean 'Choose beforehand' in any extra-biblical literature, Greek or Jewish anywhere. It always clearly means 'to know before' or 'foreknow' usually in a prophetic sense. And if one is willing to entertain theological views outside of Calvinism, then the definition 'Foreknow' fits beautifully in Romans 8:29. (BTW-Arminians differ on whether this matters for theirposition-I think it strengthens their position, but many don't think it's a necessary point). In any case, Lexicons should give definitions based on some convincing evidence...especially BDAG (which cites ancient sources outside the NT in it's very title!)  So this example, and there are others, demonstrates why I have learned to double check ALL lexicons and their claims.  Especially when any sort of debate is involved. Double check their claims by looking at the use of the term for yourself. This is very simple with one of the professional grade software programs out there. BibleWorks 8.0 is my current favorite, but there are others that can call up all uses of any term in a wide array of ancient literature (especially Jewish literature from 300 BC through 200 AD.<br /><br />Inspite of this big warning, summed up by a quote from Dr. Greg Beale at Wheaton College Grad School, \\"All Lexicons are commentaries\\", and inspite of the bias I find in this Lexical commentary, it is still a valuable tool and worthy of a five star. I still use it all the time, just double check the notes to make sure there is no bias.position-I think it strengthens their position, but many don't think it's a necessary point). In any case, Lexicons should give definitions based on some convincing evidence...especially BDAG (which cites ancient sources outside the NT in it's very title!)  So this example, and there are others, demonstrates why I have learned to double check ALL lexicons and their claims.  Especially when any sort of debate is involved. Double check their claims by looking at the use of the term for yourself. This is very simple with one of the professional grade software programs out there. BibleWorks 8.0 is my current favorite, but there are others that can call up all uses of any term in a wide array of ancient literature (especially Jewish literature from 300 BC through 200 AD.<br /><br />Inspite of this big warning, summed up by a quote from Dr. Greg Beale at Wheaton College Grad School, \\"All Lexicons are commentaries\\", and inspite of the bias I find in this Lexical commentary, it is still a valuable tool and worthy of a five star. I still use it all the time, just double check the notes to make sure there is no bias.

B0000028M7|5.0|Dirt (1992.), Alice In Chains' second studio album<br /><br />When most casual fans of early 90's alternative rock are asked who they reckoned were the most important of the Seattle grunge bands, they often say Pearl Jam, Nirvana or Soundgarden. However, this far from the case. Alice In Chains were another band who were herded under the Seattle grunge umbrella. Quintessentially a heavy metal outfit, the bands sombre and depressing lyrical and melodic outset saw to them as being part of the movement. 'Dirt' was Alice In Chains' follow up to their debut release 'Facelift' but was more importantly released at a time when grunge rock had gone pretty much mainstream. 'Dirt' has gone on to become a massive selling album for the band and is also hailed by many fans as AIC's definitive album; so is this a true reflection?<br /><br />To me, this album is more than just the definitive and greatest album by Alice In Chains; to me it is the greatest album of early 90's alternative rock. Albums such as 'Ten' or 'Superunknown' are awesome, barely flawed works, but this effort by AIC is, to me, even greater. Alice In Chains capture the spirit of grunge more than any band. The downbeat metal riffs played by Jimmy Cantrell coupled with the tortured, powerful and often depressing lyrics sung by Layne Staley is proof of this. The 'grunge' themes of drug addiction, pessimism, suicide and being down and out are everywhere in this album and seems all too real on this album more than any other grunge classic. For me, it often seems weird that I listen to this album so much, given its downbeat, depressing and difficult nature but strangely you feel drawn to and compelled to listen to this album; its that powerful. I personally wouldn't ever hesitate to put the work in my top five albums of all time without a shadow of doubt.<br /><br />AIC though, as I've said though were also your classic metal band. Throughout the album there are thunderous riffs; some racing (eg. 'Dam That River') and some slow and melodic (i.e. Dirt); not to mention plenty of great solos from Jimmy Cantrell's guitar. This album is furthermore a powerful but chiling listen because of the fact that Layne Staley is no longer actually alive. Listening to his tortured, twisted but remarkably powerful voice singing on issues keyly drug taking, in the knowledge that he died from a drug overdose sends a chill down your spine when you listen to this album, believe me. It makes 'Dirt' all the more a difficult listen but at the same time an even more stronger album. Every song on the album is strong, there are few cracks on the album.<br /><br />The album begins with 'Them Bones', a short blasting rocker. Layne Staley's pained screams as the track opens sets the style for the album. This strong opener is followed up by 'Dam That River', a fast paced classic metal song. This song takes no prisoners with its strong style. Staley's lyrics are clever on this song. Next the longer songs set in; 'Rain When I Die' is first. A warped downbeat start leads into a classic riff - Staley's pessimistic demons are there throughout in the lyrics. Next the quieter and strangely beautiful 'Down In A Hole' weaves its greatness. A song about losing the will to succeed, live or achieve anything is this songs theme, a great contrast to the melody of the song. Things then get more aggressive with 'Sickman', plenty of mad lyrics and downcast, inspired riffing call this track home. Then we come to the album's centrepiece, 'Rooster'. A Vietnam inspired song, the guitar sequence opening this song is timeless. The chorus is amazing; with Staley sing 'They've come to snuff the rooster' to some thunderous guitar play; a classic song.<br /><br />However, for me 'Junkhead' is the albums greatest achievement. The song, yes, you've guessed is about drug abuse and its dangers and its made all the more powerful by the fact Staley himself succombed to drug overdose. The lyrical wails on this song are chilling and the 'What's my drug of choice' chorus is a killer. The title track 'Dirt' follows this. Depressing, doom filled, this track is all about negatives - this song is the epitomy of creating the aura of worthlessness. Things then let up slightly with 'Godsmack'. A classic metal sounding song though Staley gives 'some' respite from the ultra depressing lyrics. Following this is a little 40 second 'Dream Sequence', with pounding guitar chords and demon laughs which then leads into 'Hate To Feel', another track were Staley sings about being down and troubled. 'Angry Chair' follows; dark in nature but masterfully crafted. Then we come to 'Would?' which has become an AIC fan favourite. This song is complex and its not quite clear what Staley really wants to convey; however the mystery of the track on top of the songs great riff makes this one a killer - the final line of 'If I would, would you?' leaves the album on a mysterious and haunting note.<br /><br />Alice In Chains, for as much of a fan following as they have, still remain a criminally underrated band. Many ignore their contribution to 90's rock with their great album efforts - they have proven to be very influential besides. 'Dirt' for me is the epitomy of 'grunge'. The band only made three albums but that contribution to rock is more than great; 'Dirt' is the centrepiece of this and more than deserves to go down as one of the greatest albums ever...'What's my drug of choice' chorus is a killer. The title track 'Dirt' follows this. Depressing, doom filled, this track is all about negatives - this song is the epitomy of creating the aura of worthlessness. Things then let up slightly with 'Godsmack'. A classic metal sounding song though Staley gives 'some' respite from the ultra depressing lyrics. Following this is a little 40 second 'Dream Sequence', with pounding guitar chords and demon laughs which then leads into 'Hate To Feel', another track were Staley sings about being down and troubled. 'Angry Chair' follows; dark in nature but masterfully crafted. Then we come to 'Would?' which has become an AIC fan favourite. This song is complex and its not quite clear what Staley really wants to convey; however the mystery of the track on top of the songs great riff makes this one a killer - the final line of 'If I would, would you?' leaves the album on a mysterious and haunting note. <br /> <br />Alice In Chains, for as much of a fan following as they have, still remain a criminally underrated band. Many ignore their contribution to 90's rock with their great album efforts - they have proven to be very influential besides. 'Dirt' for me is the epitomy of 'grunge'. The band only made three albums but that contribution to rock is more than great; 'Dirt' is the centrepiece of this and more than deserves to go down as one of the greatest albums ever...

B000AL730O|4.0|First off, I know this sounds cliche, but this album is a grower. I liked \\"Jenny Wren\\" and \\"This Never Happened Before\\" when I listened the first time, but the rest of the stuff didn't do anything for me. But after a few listens, I've realized there are some other very good songs on here, along with some stuff I'll be skipping over every time. <br /> <br />Many reviewers have complained about this being a boring album. Gimme a break. A song doesn't have to be fast, heavy, and catchy to be good. If you feel otherwise, stick to Linkin Park or something like that. <br /> <br />Aside from the excellent opener \\"Fine Line,\\" and \\"Promise to You Girl,\\" the songs are all mellow. And the stripped-down arrangements contribute to that feeling. But I like it, and think it adds a lot to the mood of the album. <br /> <br />And CACITB, like every McCartney album, has its share of garbage.  Do yourself a favor and skip At the Mercy, A Certain Softness, and Follow Me. Promise to You Girl is catchy, but a bad song.  <br /> <br />The rest of the album is very good. Highlights are Jenny Wren (love that White Album sound), Too Much Rain, Friends to Go, and This Never Happened. And the last track, Anyway, is pretty solid, too. <br /> <br />And I think this album is clearly an improvement over its predecessor Driving Rain. That album had 4 or 5 pretty good songs  and a ton of throwaways. The whole second half of the album (except Magic) was pure crap. So this album is a big improvement.  But it's still got a decent amount of filler, and that means it doesn't come close to Band on the Run.

The entry fee is 25,000 and the prize is half a million dollars. He has most of his stake and lots of people owe him money but everything seems to go wrong as he tries to collect the money due him, always with hilarious results. As he makes his way towards to tournament, he encounters another gambler, played by Jodie Foster, who also wants to enter the tournament. She too is a bit short of a stake and will stop at nothing to get into the tournament and this includes playing the vamp and the pickpocket. The final main character is the US Marshall played by James Garner. He does not seem interested in playing poker but he is on his way to the tournament as well. He has been hired to provide security. <br /> <br />As they make their way to the big event, all three of the protagonists take their shots at the others. The Indians get involved and come across as the funniest, most honest and most intelligent people around. They finally get Maverick his stake (with lots of laughs) and the stage is set for the big tournament. <br /> <br />The tournament itself is full of laughs, surprises, twists and turns. It also has a lot of cameo appearances from old time western stars. All of this is fun but the interplay between Gibson, Foster and Garner is the real fun.  <br /> <br />Get this one for the laughs and then prepare to hold your sides while you bust a gut laughing. <br />

B000B0WODA|4.0|These guys from Scotland struck gold with Take Me Out. I only expected more of the same. As is the case with sophomore albums by other bands who tread the line between being radio friendly and artistically credible, like the Strokes and the Shins, they have slightly lost a bit of the magic from, as   Beck put it, \\"busting out onto the scene.\\"  Of course, it must be hard with such a vast fanbase to create something new and yet appeal to the core listeners. They have succeeded in doing just that in this album - hooking up those who listened before, and maybe even attracting a new fan or two.   Don't expect anything exotic here. It is simple infectious danceable pop. You will want to see them play these songs live, in a drunken mob, swaggering. This is the musical equivalent of nutrasweet, so I don't think I will still be listening in four years. They have a wealth of talent that they are hiding in order to sell a lot of records and buy a lot of new jackets, which is respectable, I think, so long as they don't morph into Weezer.   But do not let this detract from the quality of this feast for the ears. Highlights:  1. The Fallen - Delivers a crisp hook with a tasty variation toward the end.  7. Eleanor Put Your Boots On - Commanding melody, vocals that will make you reconsider Eleanor (Fiery Furnaces) 's oft-wailed about blues.  12. Fade Together - I suppose this song is about moral decay and mortality, but I could be reading too much into it. I delight in the drumline.

B000B9EY2U|5.0|Basically, what Depeche Mode has done with \\"Playing the Angel\\" is rewrite the history of modern music. It's back to the drawing board for Rolling Stone magazine, which will now have <br />to rewrite its essential Top 200 albums of all times. SPIN magazine will have to rewrite its Top 200 of all times, and the British publication Q will have to rewrite its essential Top <br />200. This album is so amazing, so mind-blowing, and so robust, that its hard to even find where to begin in an effort to describe it.  <br /> <br />Let's start with Dave Gahan, whose voice has never sounded better, and whose individual contributions to a DM album have never been so crucial. Or should I start with Martin Gore, <br />whose song-writing and sequenced arrangements have never sounded so lush, so exact, and so lavish. Or should I start with the supporting cast of other musicians and producers, who <br />meshed with the inner core of DM, and pushed their sound, and their creativity into the outer edges of the stratoshpere. Unlike other reviewers of this album, i'm not going to waste  <br />any time comparing it to prior DM albums, as there is no comparison. This album stands alone by itself as without a doubt being the greatest DM album ever released, and it will go down arguably as one of the greatest albums ever made in the history of modern music. And notice that I said \\"modern music\\", and not \\"electronica\\", nor \\"alternative\\" music. <br /> <br />The album gets things going with \\"A Pain That I'm Used To\\", a song that starts off with a synth sample reminiscent of a World War II air raid siren, as if to signify that something of huge importance was about to drop right out of the sky. But instead of some type of bomb, DM drops an infectious synth loop, on top of killer, thumping drumbeat, that will instantly have your foot stomping, and your head bopping. <br />The next song, \\"John the Revelator\\" took me by surprise. Upon seeing the title, I had no idea what to expect from this one, butthe keyboard programming was utterly remarkable, the arrangement was tight, and Dave Gahan did things in this song with his voice that I never knew he was even capable of doing. Then comes track number 3, a song that Dave wrote titled  <br />\\"Suffer Well\\". This song blew my shoes, my socks, my shirt, and my pants off with its hard-driving beat, and hypnotic guitar riff. The guitar riff sounded like something straight off the Peter Gunn soundtrack, with its calculated precision, and its retro feel. Never has a guitar riff sounded so sweet in a DM song. \\"Suffer Well\\" will arguably go down in history as one of the best DM songs ever recorded. The groove continues with cut number 4, \\"The Sinner in Me\\", which is just plain and simple, classic DM. Track number 5 is the first single \\"Precious\\", which keeps the magical journey titled \\"Playing the Angel\\" going with another tight beat, and more examples of just how incredible the synth programming is on this album. And to all the reviewers out here who keep saying this song sounds out of place on this album, I beg to disagree. This song is a perfect transition between \\"The Sinner in Me\\", and track number 6, a song titled \\"Macro\\". \\"Macro\\" is another example of classic DM  <br />lyrics, layered on top of a classic DM sound. Also, the lead vocals in this song are absolutely incredible. \\"Macro\\" is just an utterly amazing song. I could go on and on for hours about the first 6 songs I just briefly overviewed, and I could go on and on for hours about the last 6 songs, however i'm going to just end it here. Of course you will have to listen for yourself and be your own judge, but whether you are a fan from back in the day, or this is the first DM album you've ever heard, I seriously doubt that you will be disappointed.  <br />

B00007ELEL|5.0|The plot is simple enough: Stoned loser is mistaken for someone else, and accidentally becomes caught up in what may or may not be a kidnapping, occasionally accompanied by his slightly crazed bowling pal. We've all seen that a million times. But as usual, the Coen brothers deliver a movie  that's unlike anything you've ever seen- dream sequences that echo Busby Berkly musicals, starring the stoned, robe wearing Dude? A mustachioed cowboy- played by Sam Elliott- who shows up briefly to provide a bit of narration and perspective? What's going on here? What's going on is  an outrageous, hilarious comedy probably unlike any film you've ever seen. It's good natured throughout, even at its most (seemingly) violent moments. Like all Coen Brothers films it's filled with memorable characters- John Turutrro's violet clad bowler, Steve Buscemei's dimwitted \\"Donny\\", an entirely over the top John Goodman as The Dude's wound way too tight bowling partner, Phillip Seymour Hoffman in yet another of his curious little characters, and many more. Don't watch this one with the kids- as The Stranger says to The Dude, \\" Do you have to use so many cuss words?\\" But for the grownups, it's a winner.
B000A7DVR2|4.0|The Big Lebowski needs no introduction to its legions of fans, but we get just that: a brand new introduction by Mortimer Young of Forever Young film preservation.  This Coen brothers' character gives a short introduction to, as he calls it, \\"The Grand Lebowski.\\"  There's a little more to this DVD than a silly introduction.  Improved picture and sound quality bring some welcome improvements to the watching experience, but only to discerning ears.  Unfortunately, modern commercial DVD tactics infiltrate the Dude's new disc, with previews automatically popping up at the beginning.   <br /> <br /> The quality of the sound is improved over the original DVD version.  Though the menu music sounds decidedly low-fi, the movie itself sounds great; one Lebowski urban achiever who screened this collector's edition with me noticed at least two places in the first ten minutes where the audio has been cleaned up from the original DVD release, starting right off the bat with the opening song Tumbling Tumbleweeds.  The movie does sound better than the original DVD. <br /> <br /> The image quality appears to be improved over the first version, and it can be fairly noticeable in nighttime scenes.  The first dream sequence displays a very sharp night view of Los Angeles.  Unfortunately, other parts of the movie are not as nice, with some artifacts and noise popping up in the blue sky; these minor problems can be fairly easily overlooked, though.  On the whole, though, the video is improved over the original DVD release. <br /> <br /> The special features are nothing to write home about - a pre-programmed three minute 20 second slide show are all we get of Jeff Bridges's photography from the film's set, though a few interesting shots and notes pop up.  Simply getting a behind the scenes look is interesting, though not alone worth paying to buy the movie again.  The Production Notes contain a few bits of trivia, but nothing too revelatory for most Lebowski fanatics. <br /> <br /> The improved image and sound quality will be a welcome improvement to audio and videophiles, but the video is not as flawless as one may expect.  If you don't already own a copy, pick up the new version, the improved images are worth a couple extra dollars.   <br /> <br /> The biggest questions for many Lebowski fans may be, \\"Should I buy this again?  Do I need a second copy of Lebowski for my collection?\\"  If you have a little spare cash in your budget, rediscover the movie with a slightly better image version and much clearer audio.  But let's hope for something much better in the future; this may be a ringer, but it's filled with something better than just the dirty undies, man.
B000B2YQX4|5.0|DM is my favorite band of all time. I don't feel like I've listened to this album enough times yet to make a perfect judgement, and my opinion may well change in the future, but this is what I think at the moment. <br /> <br />This is a very good album, more than worthy of 5 stars, but they do have better ones. <br /> <br />Pros: <br />o All the songs are very good, but some are particularly great; right now I'm particularly fond of Precious, Suffer Well, and Damaged People. <br />o I agree with what people have said, that Precious is one of their best singles. <br />o It's a DM album, and anything at all by them is great, far above most other bands <br /> <br />Cons: <br />o A little too much guitar at times.  I'm a big fan of synth, and while some guitar (especially accoustic) can be nice at times, I can always tell where synth would have sounded 100% better to me if they'd used it instead of guitar (this applies to most bands, not just DM). <br />o Sounds at times like they were purposely backing away from the Exciter sound somewhat, and I love Exciter, one of their best albums.  I don't mind a move in a new direction, that's good, but I never like when bands purposely avoiding past albums and sounds and such, because those almost always turn out to be things I particularly liked. <br />o It seems like it could have used a little more work in the studio here and there, because it sounds a little rough in a few places, maybe intentionally, but maybe not.  And there's a few particularly strong ideas in some of the tracks that I wish had been pursued more fully, maybe extended farther into the rest of the song (like a particularly dramatic moment in Suffer Well that could have been the basis of a whole song ideaon it's own).  There's a making-of on the DVD and (if I'm remembering right) the guy working with them on the album seemed very proud of the concept that they were hurrying the recording process.  I'm not so sure that was such a good idea, and maybe the album could have been even better with some more time on it. <br /> <br /> <br />A few reviewers have said they don't like Damaged People that much, but I have to totally and completely disagree: it is a GREAT song.  It is a little experimental sounding (to me that's a good thing), and also sounds very DM to me, as well (frankly, I wish they'd done a few more tracks along these lines).  I'd go farther by saying that every song on the album is very strong quality. <br /> <br />All that said, I still fully expect to be doing another review in the future once I get more familiar with this album.  But I think this will remain at 5 stars. <br />
B00005JOI3|4.0|Visually, this movie was amazing.  There were so many visual trickeries in this movie that my eyes were glued to the screen, hoping not to miss any cool details.  \\"Stay\\" heavily deals with the question, \\"what is real?\\" and if you pay attention to what's going on in the background, you'll be asking \\"is this real?\\" too.  In fact, I heard one guy in the theater blurt out, \\"what the *bleep* is going on??\\" in one scene.<br /><br />What I really enjoyed was the fact that the visuals, despite all the cool trickeries, did not seem overwhelming or over the top.  In fact, it came just short of being over the top.  In less capable hands, all the cool camera angles, fades and transitions, filter effects, and interior set pieces would have ended up being overblown and cheesy.  The director Marc Foster and all the people behind cinematography, CG effects, and production design deserve a major standing ovation for their efforts.<br /><br />I'm being more subjective here, but I absolutely loved the music too.  Fittingly atmospheric and trippy, the music adeptly underscored the visuals, and I'll be sure to get the soundtrack CD.<br /><br />However, I have to say that I took objection to the movie's use of the song \\"Angel\\" by Massive Attack.  Now, I love Massive Attack, and I really like the song \\"Angel.\\"  It's just that I've already heard that same song used in dreamy/trippy scenes in several other movies.  Massive Attack's vibe fits the movie perfectly well, so I don't mind their choice in the band.  But why couldn't they use one of Massive Attack's lesser known but just as atmospheric and trippy songs instead?  Hearing that song in \\"Stay\\" made me go, \\"oh no, not again,\\" and took me out of the film.<br /><br />All in all, \\"Stay\\" was a huge treat for my eyes and ears.<br /><br />Beyond all the production gloss, however, I have to confess that I walked away from the theater feeling a bit underwhelmed.  There just wasn't enough substance to tie it all together.  A lot of the visual cool stuff ended up being just that: cool stuff, and nothing more.  It's like receiving a big gift box, spending time rattling it to guess what's inside, only to unwrap it and discover that it's just one piece of Godiva chocolate in a big fluffy packaging.  Still delicious, and you'd rather have it than not, but at the same time, it's disappointing, and the joy is too fleeting.  Without all the visual fluff, the story of \\"Stay\\" probably could have been told in one 45-minute \\"Outer Limits\\" or \\"Twilight Zone\\" episode.<br /><br />Acting-wise, I thought Ryan Gosling hit the perfect note for his role.  Naomi Watts gave a decent, if not particularly memorable, performance.  Ewan McGregor's performance, however, was a bit of a mixed bag.  There were moments where I thought he nailed it perfectly, and then there were moments where I thought he simply fell flat.  I like Ewan, but he more often than not seems to have at least one such moment in all his films, and that's such a shame.<br /><br />Speaking of which, I have to say that Bob Hoskins was amazing.  He was amazing in \\"Unleashed,\\" and he was amazing in \\"Stay.\\"  And sadly, his performance will probably go unnoticed by many.<br /><br />Overall, I enjoyed this movie.  I'm a sucker for \\"what is real?\\"-type storylines, and if \\"Stay\\" had more substance to it, I probably would have given it a 4.5-star rating.  As it is, the movie deserves about 3 or 3.5 stars.  But I really, really loved the visual flair of this film, and I dug the atmosphere it created.  And since Amazon won't let me do ratings in 0.5 increments, I'm bumping it up to a 4-star rating.<br /><br />By the way, if you are interested in watching this film, then do go to a theater and watch it on a big screen.  I feel that \\"Stay\\"'s visual flair just won't be the same on a smaller TV screen.visual cool stuff ended up being just that: cool stuff, and nothing more.  It's like receiving a big gift box, spending time rattling it to guess what's inside, only to unwrap it and discover that it's just one piece of Godiva chocolate in a big fluffy packaging.  Still delicious, and you'd rather have it than not, but at the same time, it's disappointing, and the joy is too fleeting.  Without all the visual fluff, the story of \\"Stay\\" probably could have been told in one 45-minute \\"Outer Limits\\" or \\"Twilight Zone\\" episode. <br /> <br />Acting-wise, I thought Ryan Gosling hit the perfect note for his role.  Naomi Watts gave a decent, if not particularly memorable, performance.  Ewan McGregor's performance, however, was a bit of a mixed bag.  There were moments where I thought he nailed it perfectly, and then there were moments where I thought he simply fell flat.  I like Ewan, but he more often than not seems to have at least one such moment in all his films, and that's such a shame. <br /> <br />Speaking of which, I have to say that Bob Hoskins was amazing.  He was amazing in \\"Unleashed,\\" and he was amazing in \\"Stay.\\"  And sadly, his performance will probably go unnoticed by many. <br /> <br />Overall, I enjoyed this movie.  I'm a sucker for \\"what is real?\\"-type storylines, and if \\"Stay\\" had more substance to it, I probably would have given it a 4.5-star rating.  As it is, the movie deserves about 3 or 3.5 stars.  But I really, really loved the visual flair of this film, and I dug the atmosphere it created.  And since Amazon won't let me do ratings in 0.5 increments, I'm bumping it up to a 4-star rating. <br /> <br />By the way, if you are interested in watching this film, then do go to a theater and watch it on a big screen.  I feel that \\"Stay\\"'s visual flair just won't be the same on a smaller TV screen.

B0000029J5|5.0|Keb' Mo' sings in a deep, mellow voice and plays a beautiful guitar, including a National; he has a special way of immediately capturing your attention and not letting go till he's done. He is at his absolute best when staying within the old blues tradition (12-bar, down-home tunes, just him and his guitar): his version of Robert Johnson's KINDHEARTED WOMAN is a perfect example of this. It goes right to the gut emotionally, but is still lyrical and melodic. Other highlights are EVERY MORNING and LOVE BLUES (he also blows harp on this last mentioned tune).There are a couple of duds on the CD, but the better performances are so good they make up for them. Worth checking out.
